story:
Why a Beehive?

 

A beehive is a natural collective, formed by a series of individuals who contribute unique skills and processes to enrich their community as a whole. 'The Beehive', therefore, felt like the perfect metaphor for the project: a public art installation that champions community cohesion and celebrates individuals, offering them a supportive space to exhibit their skill sets and methods of self-expression. The project supports the environment through collaborating with local hives, the rewards of wildflower seeds and the recycling of donated clothing.

 

The Beehive project can be split into two main chunks: The Build and The Tour.

 

 

The Build:

 

The build of The Beehive aims to involve local communities around Tolworth, Kingston, Surbiton, Long Ditton, and surrounding areas in various ways. To make the internal lining of The Beehive, I am running free inclusive creative workshops with schools, hospitals, care homes and an array of social groups. I will be teaching individuals new skills and encouraging people to work together. An international open call for handmade bees is running until July 10th, inviting creatives to submit their work to be exhibited in the Beehive as it tours. Recycled textiles will be used to make the lining - those donated with a personal memory will feature in the project's book (published by Sampson Low Ltd).  The geodesic structure will be built using local materials in collaboration with SHEDx and the design and architecture firm the 121 Collective. 

 

 

The Tour:

 

The Beehive installation will tour the local area visiting a variety of public spaces for a minimum of 3 months. The Beehive will be a constantly evolving space full of workshops, performances, film screenings, talks, events and more, highlighting all the creative talent existing in the local area and giving people an accessible platform to playfully experiment with their ideas. 

 

 

Who has supported The Beehive so far?

 

The Beehive project has had a cracking start - so far it is supported by:

  • SHEDx: A 2 year GLA funded project supporting community-led regeneration in Tolworth 
  • The Community Brain: A Community Interest Company focused on utilising people’s natural talents and energies to develop stronger communities and relationships
  • The Royal Borough of Kingston Upon Thames
  • The Mayor of London

 

How can you contribute?
 

Help fund this campaign:

  • Simply make a pledge - hit the pink BACK IT button at the top of this page
  • Pledge for one of the project's fantastic rewards - choose from a range of rewards contributed by emerging artists and local organisations
  • Invite others to make a pledge
    • To donate in GBP without conversion charge click on the total below and edit your currency settings.

Promote The Beehive:

  • Tell your friends!
  • Share The Beehive's website on social media (www.debbiechessell.com)
  • Display The Beehive flyers and posters in your establishment
  • Talk about the project on your podcast, radio show, newspaper, blog or any other platform - contact Debbie at hello@debbiechessell.com to arrange an interview

Get involved:

  • Would you like to make a bee to live in The Beehive? Download the spec form
  • Are you part of a craft group who would like to make hexagons for The Beehive? Download a template (including a knitting/crochet pattern) here
  • Do you have any unwanted yellow, orange, brown or light coloured fabrics and clothing? Post or deliver them to FAO Debbie Chessell, The Beehive, 59 Fleece Road, Long Ditton, Surbiton, Surrey, KT6 5JR
  • If you would like to share a memory associated with your fabric donation that will be featured in The Beehive book, download this form
  • Do you work with or know of a community group that could benefit from one of our workshops? Get in touch by emailing hello@debbiechessell.com
  • Would you like to run a workshop during The Beehive's tour? Fill out this proposal form
story_txt:
Why a Beehive?
 
A beehive is a natural collective, formed by a series of individuals who contribute unique skills and processes to enrich their community as a whole. 'The Beehive', therefore, felt like the perfect metaphor for the project: a public art installation that champions community cohesion and celebrates individuals, offering them a supportive space to exhibit their skill sets and methods of self-expression. The project supports the environment through collaborating with local hives, the rewards of wildflower seeds and the recycling of donated clothing.
 
The Beehive project can be split into two main chunks: The Build and The Tour.
 

 
The Build:
 
The build of The Beehive aims to involve local communities around Tolworth, Kingston, Surbiton, Long Ditton, and surrounding areas in various ways. To make the internal lining of The Beehive, I am running free inclusive creative workshops with schools, hospitals, care homes and an array of social groups. I will be teaching individuals new skills and encouraging people to work together. An international open call for handmade bees is running until July 10th, inviting creatives to submit their work to be exhibited in the Beehive as it tours. Recycled textiles will be used to make the lining - those donated with a personal memory will feature in the project's book (published by Sampson Low Ltd).  The geodesic structure will be built using local materials in collaboration with SHEDx and the design and architecture firm the 121 Collective. 
 

 
The Tour:
 
The Beehive installation will tour the local area visiting a variety of public spaces for a minimum of 3 months. The Beehive will be a constantly evolving space full of workshops, performances, film screenings, talks, events and more, highlighting all the creative talent existing in the local area and giving people an accessible platform to playfully experiment with their ideas. 
 

 
Who has supported The Beehive so far?
 
The Beehive project has had a cracking start - so far it is supported by:

SHEDx: A 2 year GLA funded project supporting community-led regeneration in Tolworth 
The Community Brain: A Community Interest Company focused on utilising people’s natural talents and energies to develop stronger communities and relationships
The Royal Borough of Kingston Upon Thames
The Mayor of London

 
How can you contribute? 
Help fund this campaign:

Simply make a pledge - hit the pink BACK IT button at the top of this page
Pledge for one of the project's fantastic rewards - choose from a range of rewards contributed by emerging artists and local organisations
Invite others to make a pledgeTo donate in GBP without conversion charge click on the total below and edit your currency settings.


Promote The Beehive:

Tell your friends!
Share The Beehive's website on social media (www.debbiechessell.com)
Display The Beehive flyers and posters in your establishment
Talk about the project on your podcast, radio show, newspaper, blog or any other platform - contact Debbie at hello@debbiechessell.com to arrange an interview

Get involved:

Would you like to make a bee to live in The Beehive? Download the spec form

Are you part of a craft group who would like to make hexagons for The Beehive? Download a template (including a knitting/crochet pattern) here

Do you have any unwanted yellow, orange, brown or light coloured fabrics and clothing? Post or deliver them to FAO Debbie Chessell, The Beehive, 59 Fleece Road, Long Ditton, Surbiton, Surrey, KT6 5JR
If you would like to share a memory associated with your fabric donation that will be featured in The Beehive book, download this form

Do you work with or know of a community group that could benefit from one of our workshops? Get in touch by emailing hello@debbiechessell.com
Would you like to run a workshop during The Beehive's tour? Fill out this proposal form

story:
The Big Picture

We are in a moment of historic change:  A crescendo of calls for racial justice, and a new openness to hearing them. Economic life, especially for those who already had less, near a breaking point. High-stakes decisions about immigration. Systemic poverty. Environmental justice. Mass incarceration. All around us, bold voices are crying out for radical love and justice in a broken world.

For 11 years, A Peace of My Mind has been growing toward this very moment. It’s time for us to seek out leaders on the front edge of change—to amplify them—and to join them in imagining new possibilities. It’s time to create a new body of work that speaks to the challenges of today and celebrates the people who are working to solve them.

In the next year, I’ll seek out people on the leading edge of these movements, as well as those directly impacted by the issues. We’ll photograph them, interview them, record the conversations, and share the results as podcasts and online stories. We’ll be looking for hope, transformation, courage, and inspiration as we develop a new series of stories called Cry Out: Voices calling for radical love and justice in a broken world.

We know you care passionately about this work and we invite you to help us expand and amplify it. This funding campaign is the first phase of a three-part process. This campaign will support travel costs to gather and edit the stories, then share them through our online platform and our podcast.

The Goal We Share

The world is filled with challenges, and it's time that we face them honestly and directly. For too long, voices that have cried out for change have gone unheard. It's time to move outside of our comfort zones. It's time to listen to new voices. It's time to challenge ourselves and the way we see the world. In the face of overwhelming odds, creative people are finding  ways to build community, correct injustice, and promote healing.

A Peace of My Mind finds those stories and amplifies them. We record those stories and hold them up as a model for how we can move forward into a more just and equitable future. We find ourselves at a unique moment in history, and through listening, we have the chance to learn how we can live better together. I'm asking you to help A Peace of My Mind document the ways the world is crying out for change and doing the hard work to make it happen.​

Why Now?

There is an urgency to this moment. These past few months have offered us a pause from what had become normal and presented an opportunity for reflection. Issues that seemed at the periphery of our awareness are now at the center, in critical focus, and we have the opportunity to reinvent the way we live our lives and the way we relate to those around us.

Over the past decade, A Peace of My Mind has developed a deep collection of stories that reflect our diverse American experience. In this moment, I want to seek out voices from the leading edge of change. I want to lend my voice to theirs and cry out for others to hear.

These years of listening have prepared me, and the pandemic has opened a space in my schedule to act boldly. This spring, unable to travel to in-person engagements but attentive to the power of personal stories, we created the podcast How Life Changed to explore this unprecedented time through the lens of individual stories. In a matter of weeks, we recorded 40 interviews and learned how to publish each as a podcast episode.

Then, with the tragic killing of George Floyd by police in Minneapolis, we brought a portable studio to the intersection of 38th and Chicago (the site where George Floyd was killed) to ask people simply, "What do you want to say?" It turned into a powerful body of work that you can see here.

Movements for racial, economic, and climate justice are more urgent by the day. We need to lift up the voices of those who are most impacted and those who are leading the way with bold vision and real solutions. A Peace of My Mind has the tools, the network, the desire, and the time to respond to this moment. With your help, I can also gather the resources to move headlong into this new series of portraits and stories.

My Backstory

I've spent three decades as a freelance photographer, shooting projects for national magazines and Fortune 500 companies. Eleven years ago, I founded A Peace of My Mind, a multimedia arts project that uses photography and storytelling to explore our common humanity. In an increasingly polarized world, A Peace of My Mind encourages us to rediscover what connects us.

Our first book and exhibits were produced in our own back yard of Minnesota. Then, a 40,000-mile road trip across the United States gathered new stories for our second book and exhibits: A Peace of My Mind: American Stories.

In recent years, we've brought our exhibits around the country and used the stories to talk about conflict resolution, civic responsibility, and social change. I've led programming at small public high schools, churches, and community centers, as well as the National Civil Rights Museum and Rutgers University's Honors College. This small little side hustle has turned into my life's work, and it keeps me running. I'm happy to run, because it feels like the world needs these messages of hope and healing more and more every day.

A Peace of My Mind has been a grass-roots passion project from the very start, and we have grown with the encouragement and support of hundreds of people who believe in the mission. Good folks have nudged us along at key times to help us grow and to keep the wheels turning.

This is one of those key times, again. Although I'm always reluctant to do so, it's time to cry out for help.

My dreams are bigger than my means at the moment. All of the relationships and connections are in place for this to happen. I have the time available to launch into this work. We just need the funding, so I'm turning to you. And it's completely up to you how big this will become.

What We Need & What You Get

This funding campaign is the first phase of a three-part process. This phase will fund travel costs to gather and edit the stories, then share them through our online platform and our podcast.

We will be a two-person crew (myself and an audio tech), and we will build our travel schedule according to the availability of our interview subjects. 

The budget will cover travel, lodging, meals, etc. while we are on the road. And once we return, it will also cover transcription services, editing, and production time to share the stories online.

We will share the content in weekly podcast episodes, on our website and our social media platforms. We'll share the experiences and the stories step-by-step as we explore solutions to our most challenging problems and we will elevate the voices of those who are leading the way toward change.

We have a collection of exciting perks to thank you for your support. Explore the page and you'll see some of our existing books, branded coins and stickers, signed press sheets, and even personal Zoom appearances for your neighborhood book clubs. At the highest levels of support, you can choose from your own legacy interview, a behind-the-scenes visit, or a presentation in your own community.

Our budget is scalable. If we don't reach our goal, we will do what we can with the money we raise, even if it means using frequent flier miles and sleeping on friends' couches. Every dollar from this campaign will go toward pushing the project forward.

If we exceed our goal, we will expand the number of interviews. We'll explore new ways of sharing them. We'll build a little team to help grow the series.

If we blow the roof off, we'll simply roll right into phases two and three and produce a book and an exhibit from the stories we gather...but let's not get ahead of ourselves just yet. Let's see how this unfolds.

The Impact

In a polarized world, we require hope. We need tools that can connect us and bridge divides, and we need examples of success in order to believe that something better is possible. A Peace of My Mind has more than ten years of experience gathering stories and using them to encourage positive conversations. We have dreamt big and asked for help and put our noses to the grindstone to get the hard work done. And we've got a track record to prove it. More than anything, we have seen the way these stories can inspire, encourage conversation, and offer hope to a world that desperately needs it. Check out a few of these testimonials from people who have engaged with our work:

“John Noltner takes us on a unique journey filled with revelations of courage and commitment, resilience and hope. It is a beautiful journey that speaks to our innermost being. It touches us in a way that allows us to see the world from a different perspective. Perhaps it will inspire us to become peacemakers.” ~ Ela Gandhi, South African peace activist and granddaughter of Mahatma Gandhi

“ A Peace of My Mind offers a much-needed salve for these painful, polarized times we live in.”        ~ Vijay Pendakur, Ed.D. Robert W. and Elizabeth C. Staley Dean of Students, Cornell University

“Mr. Noltner’s work will tug at your heart and your sense of humanity. It’s difficult to digest this work and remain indifferent. A Peace of My Mind is an encouraging stimulus to action!” ~ Terri Lee Freeman, President, National Civil Rights Museum

“I would recommend John Noltner’s work to anyone who wants to experience the diversity of human beings and the universality of the human condition.” ~ Jim Wallis, New York Times bestselling author of The UnCommon Good, president of Sojourners, and editor-in-chief of Sojourners magazine

“What sets John Noltner apart is his ability to capture not just the story, but the raw emotion and purpose through his lens. John has time and time again been able to listen and help us tell our story.” ~ Heather Ehle, CEO/Founder, Project Sanctuary

Building a Team

I say "WE" a lot when I talk about A Peace of My Mind, and it's because I recognize that none of this can happen without your help. We are, indeed, a million points of light. Imagine what we can do together. Come along for the journey.

Risks & Challenges

Some of the people I hope to interview for this series are well-known and busy individuals. We will need to be persistent and flexible to accommodate their schedules. We will strive to create an efficient travel route, but it is likely we will have to backtrack and revisit regions in order to gather the stories we need.

COVID-19 is not done yet. It's unclear exactly what the fall will look like, and we may need to adjust our plans as travel restrictions shift and as our subjects experience varying levels of comfort with meeting in person.

As mentioned earlier, the scope of this new series will be driven by the funding we raise. If the budget is limited, we will have to make choices about how many stories to tell and how we will share them. As the budget increases, we can offer more content and find new, innovative ways of sharing it (like the public projections we have been doing in Minneapolis).

More than anything, I know we will encounter unexpected challenges. This has been the story of A Peace of My Mind's journey. We are comfortable with a fluid process where we learn from each new experience, readjust the process, and embrace that new knowledge to inform our path forward. There's new learning every day, and it's part of what makes life interesting and beautiful.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some folks just won't be able to contribute financially, and that's understandable, but there are other ways you can help with the effort:

  • Tell your friends. Spread the word. If we are going to be successful, we'll have to reach far beyond our usual circles, and we'll need your help to make some noise about this campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the message on social media.
  • Share your ideas about where we should go and who we should talk with.
  • Like, comment, share, repeat. It all helps amplify our message AND it helps keep us energized during the long campaign. We need to hear that you are with us in spirit, too.

story:
Introduction of Ekoin

Nice to meet you!

We are Koya-san Shingon Sect, Jyun Bekkaku Honzan (Semi-Special Head Temple), Ekoin.

Thank you very much for visiting this page out of many campaigns.

Ekoin is a Buddhist Temple with a history of 1200 years, located in one of the world heritages, Mt. Koya, Wakayama, Japan.

It is called the Ekoin (“廻向院” in Japanese character) because the Master Kukai (a.k.a. Kobo-Daishi who is a founder of Shingon Sect) erected a five-storied pagoda in this location, and his disciple Dosho, the priest, performed “Eko” (“廻向” in Japanese), the revolving of the people (the memorial service of the ancestors) in here.  

During Hoei period (early 1700s), Ekoin is renamed to our current name by Yoshimune Tokugawa who is 8th shogun of Tokugawa Shogunate. (The name given at that time had same sound, but different character as “恵光院” )

We have two halls. Main hall enshrines Amida Nyorai (Amitabha in Sanskrit), Kukai (Kobo-Daishi), and Fudo Myo (Acalanatha in Sanskrit). And the other hall called “Bishamon Hall” enshrines Bishamon Ten (Vaisravana in Sanskrit) as its principal images.

Ekoin is also known as a Shukubo (“宿坊” in Japanese). 

Shukubo is a place where you can get the taste of monk’s life style with “Temple Lodging”. You can stay in our temple, enjoy our Shojin Ryori (Buddhist’s Vegetarian Cuisine) and experience acitivities.

A specialty experiences at Ekoin are "Homa Fire Ritual" and "Meditation". Visitors can join the Homa Fire Ritual, performed every morning with monks. And various kinds of meditation programs are offered. 

 

 

Introduction of Koya-san

Koya-san (Mt. Koya) is well known as a Headquarter of Shingon Sect Buddhism which is found by Master Kukai (Kobo-Daishi) back in 9th century. It is also known as a World Heritage certified in 2004. Therefore, Koya-san is not only a place for religious believers, but also an unique place for visitors & travelers now. Within Koya-san, there is the Master Head Temple “Kongobuji” in the middle, and many of  Head and Semi Head Temples around. Each temple has its’ own historical episodes and heritages. Every time you visit, you must find and experience something different.

 

Current Situtaion in Koya-san

Due to “COVID-19” situation, visitors to Koya-san has dramatically decreased. The number of visitors to Ekoin now is 5% of usual. If this situation continues, we will face the difficulty to preserve this historically & religiously important heritages. Your contribution will save it. 

 

About Homa Fire Ritual

Homa Fire Ritual (護摩祈祷）

The Homa Fire Ritual of consecrated fire in unique to Vajrayana and Esoteric Buddhism and is perhaps also the most mystical and cognitively powerful. It stems from the Vedie Agnihotra Ritual and is performed by qualified priests and acharyas for the benefit of individuals, the state or all sentient beings in general. The consecrated fire is believed to have a powerful cleansing effect spiritually and psychologically. The ritual is performed for the purpose of destroying negative energies, detrimental thoughts and desires, and for the making of secular requests and blessings. In most Shingon Sect Temples, this ritual is performed daily in the morning or the afternoon, and is a requirement for all for all acharyas to learn this ritual upon entering the priesthood. Larger scale ceremonies often include the constant beating of taiko drums and mass chanting of the mantra of Acalanatha by priests and lay practitioners. Flames can sometimes reach a few meters high. The combination of the ritual's visuals and sounds can be trance-inducing and make for a profound experience.

Homa Stick (添護摩木）

Homa Stick is a wood for burning when a holy fire is lighted. Wishes and Names of prayers will be written on it, and a priest burns it in the Homa Fire Ritual. 

Picture of Homa Fire Ritual at Ekoin

Picture of Homa Stick (Left)

 

 

Ekoin x CMK Collaboration

Ekoin is collaborating with world's famous Tattoo/Graffiti artist, TAKIZO MORO who belongs to CMK. Some of our perks are very unique collaboration items with him. Please check it out!

■CMK Gallery

One of the top street artist groups established in 1990.

CMK is now providing art working by their unique style which is various kinds of cultures acquired by their base style, Graffiti. With that style, CMK is working for several fields such as company logo, CD jackets, Wall Painting, etc.

In 2013, CMK opened a physical store next to their studio in Osaka. At there, CMK is performing exhibitions and selling their art works and original items.  

CMK is trying to pursuing the establishment of wealthy and healthy environment. And as an interface of Japanese Street Art Culture, CMK will discover and take up the vibrant talents and dedicate to be a bridge between cultures and arts through their projects. 

Web Site : https://cmkgallery.jp

 

■TAKIZO MORO（茂呂竹蔵）

Well known as a Graffiti/Tattoo Artist belongs to CMK.

Started his career as a graffiti artist in the 90's. Moved his scene to New York in 2002. He left a lot of Pieces and Throw-Ups in San Francisco, Bronx, and Brooklyn. In addition to that, while he was in New York, he started his private exhibition in Manhattan. As his significant work in the US, Takizo has tattooed Adam Levine, a vocalist from Grammy Award winning band, Maroon 5. 

His style, a fusion of Japanese traditional style such as Ukiyoe(浮世絵）or Yamatoe（大和絵）and contemporary street arts like graffiti is highly acclaimed world widely.  

Recent works & achievements

-"Bishamon Ten (Vaisravana)" art work dedicated to Ekoin, a temple in a world heritage, Koya-san 

-First Place of New York Empire State Tattoo Expo 2017, Best Traditional

-Amulet design for Wakinomiya Shrine, Kyoto, Japan

-"Dragon" art work donated to Western Japan Heavy Rain Relief 

Twitter : @takizomoro

Instagram : https://www.instagram.com/takizomoro

 

 

 

Why we started this project & What we want to do

Under the COVID-19 situation, people all over the world are asked self-restraint (or maybe stricter in some places) to go out. Of course, “going abroad” is out of question now. People cannot come and pray in  Koya-san even if they wanted to. We understand this is a necessary sacrifice.

Under such a situation, we monks at Ekoin discussed,

 

What can we do for the world?

What can we do for Koya-san?

How can we help the world?

How can we preserve the history, culture, heritage, and people in here?

 

And we reached an answer,

 

What we monks can do is “pray for the world from here”.

This is our motivation to start this campaign. 

 

 

What you'll get from contribution

-We will pray "World Peace" and "World Health" instead of backers. 

-Backers will receive unique return items depend on the amount of contribution. All items will be prayed by monks in Ekoin with certain traditional praying ceremony. Please check out the all perks we offer.

-Through your contribution, you can save not only temple itself, but people's life working for Koya-san temples such as craftsman in here, cooks in here etc.

 

Finally

Thank you for reading to the end.

Ekoin sincerely pray that the coronavirus pandemic will end as soon as possible and everyone will be able to visit Koya-san.

Until people come to a peaceful world without any conflicts, we monks offer prayers. So that you can relieve the suffering of living things.  Gassho (合掌)

 

This project will be implemented in the flexible funding. Even the total contributions are less than target amount we set, we will perform all perks to the backers.

Introduction of Ekoin Nice to meet you!We are Koya-san Shingon Sect, Jyun Bekkaku Honzan (Semi-Special Head Temple), Ekoin.Thank you very much for visiting this page out of many campaigns.Ekoin is a Buddhist Temple with a history of 1200 years, located in one of the world heritages, Mt. Koya, Wakayama, Japan.It is called the Ekoin (“廻向院” in Japanese character) because the Master Kukai (a.k.a. Kobo-Daishi who is a founder of Shingon Sect) erected a five-storied pagoda in this location, and his disciple Dosho, the priest, performed “Eko” (“廻向” in Japanese), the revolving of the people (the memorial service of the ancestors) in here.  During Hoei period (early 1700s), Ekoin is renamed to our current name by Yoshimune Tokugawa who is 8th shogun of Tokugawa Shogunate. (The name given at that time had same sound, but different character as “恵光院” )We have two halls. Main hall enshrines Amida Nyorai (Amitabha in Sanskrit), Kukai (Kobo-Daishi), and Fudo Myo (Acalanatha in Sanskrit). And the other hall called “Bishamon Hall” enshrines Bishamon Ten (Vaisravana in Sanskrit) as its principal images.Ekoin is also known as a Shukubo (“宿坊” in Japanese). Shukubo is a place where you can get the taste of monk’s life style with “Temple Lodging”. You can stay in our temple, enjoy our Shojin Ryori (Buddhist’s Vegetarian Cuisine) and experience acitivities.A specialty experiences at Ekoin are "Homa Fire Ritual" and "Meditation". Visitors can join the Homa Fire Ritual, performed every morning with monks. And various kinds of meditation programs are offered.   Introduction of Koya-sanKoya-san (Mt. Koya) is well known as a Headquarter of Shingon Sect Buddhism which is found by Master Kukai (Kobo-Daishi) back in 9th century. It is also known as a World Heritage certified in 2004. Therefore, Koya-san is not only a place for religious believers, but also an unique place for visitors & travelers now. Within Koya-san, there is the Master Head Temple “Kongobuji” in the middle, and many of  Head and Semi Head Temples around. Each temple has its’ own historical episodes and heritages. Every time you visit, you must find and experience something different. Current Situtaion in Koya-san Due to “COVID-19” situation, visitors to Koya-san has dramatically decreased. The number of visitors to Ekoin now is 5% of usual. If this situation continues, we will face the difficulty to preserve this historically & religiously important heritages. Your contribution will save it.  About Homa Fire RitualHoma Fire Ritual (護摩祈祷）The Homa Fire Ritual of consecrated fire in unique to Vajrayana and Esoteric Buddhism and is perhaps also the most mystical and cognitively powerful. story:
MUSEUM OF MOBILE ART

The Museum of Mobile Art is  Melissa E. Logan (musician and artist), Jakob S. Boeskov (filmmaker and artist) and K.O. Nnamdie (executive curator). We believe in the power of art to transform, to uplift - especially in time of crisis. Museums are closed, therefore we will practice a method of cultural appreciation in the open air, an interactive museum without walls. We want you to join us!

It's our pleasure to offer you a chance to take part in our joyous journey from New York to Tennessee. The late, great Andy Warhol famously called the American zones between Los Angeles and New York "Fly-Over Country" and that's exactly where we're going! 

 

 

A SIMPLE SOLUTION

The mission is delightfully simple: To bring sculptures, banners and prints from world-renowned artists and newbies to areas beyond the main cultural capitals. We are escaping the mega city of New York, to come face to face - at a safe distance - in parks and public spaces, with art lovers and coincidental bystanders, in open air happenings. We aim for collaborations with local artists, building a dialogue with the artworks we bring from New York. Museum of Mobile Art  celebrates big ideas in small formats, easy storage, mobility, instantaneous happenings, at breakneck speed. We print it, we post it, and we perform it. The world is moving at internet speed, and so are we. Every day is marked by a sunrise, and by sunset the performance is happening. Everything will be documented in 4K footage, to be posted on our YouTube channel. We will drive our art-van full speed into the present moment: It's 2020, an election year in a hurting and divided world, and we are here to help. Today aspects of the art world that used to make sense suddenly seem absurd, but that's no excuse to stop making art. We believe it's time to embrace this new absurdity, to journey into a wonderful and frightening world, head first, in a van filled with art, costumes and a portable sound system.

 

HOW CAN YOU SUPPORT?

We are cheap, we are fast, we are ecstatic. But yes, we do in fact need funds for vehicle rental, for gas, water and art printing materials. In order to do so, we are humbly asking for your support. The minimum donation is $25. Should you have the ability to donate more, we are offering you special art prizes.

 

WHY IS THIS IMPORTANT?

In the spirit of total democracy we want to foster and help seed new art communities, to meet individuals, to expand minds, especially our own. We offer possibilities for others to join us for the ride. As artists coming from cultural deserts/rural areas, we acknowledge how important it is to have strangers come and deliver divergent ways of art and life.

 

RISK AND CHALLENGES

We are  artist/producers with years of experience working with various institutions like Tate Britain, MoMA, National Museum of Modern Art, Kyoto and The Centre Pompidou, just to name a few. On the ground projects include out-reach brunch programs to the homeless in our neighborhoods, building musical instruments for refugee kids in Munich, Germany. Our challenge now is urgency and speed. We are simply looking to rent a vehicle and purchase art materials /prints that will allow us to put on art shows in Tennessee. Should we raise too little funding our car will be of bad quality, and we will sleep on sofas with friends. Should we raise more, we will have funding for higher quality/larger prints, and also motels which will allow us to focus better on the art happenings.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you don't have the means to contribute, please feel free to ask your friends to get the word out and make some noise about our mobile art happening.

story:
Microscope must unexpectedly move from its long-time space in Bushwick Brooklyn by the end of April. We are seeking your help to create a new home that will allow us to continue and expand our programming, especially our weekly Event Series of time-based arts, which we have been preparing to resume in-person — after more than a year online — as soon as it is safely possible.

Your support will help us transform the new space we have found near the High Line in Manhattan to house our now 10 1/2 year-long Event Series that includes screenings of all formats (film, analog & digital video, etc.) music and experimental sound nights, performance art, expanded cinema, poetry, artist talks and more.

Although it has been a difficult decision to leave our current space and neighborhood, we are excited about this new chapter for Microscope and hope that you will contribute to make this transition possible!

For those who would like tax-deductible options please visit our companion campaign on Fractured Atlas HERE.

The total amount we must raise through both campaigns is $30,000.

 

Please Note: All perks will be available at the gallery for local pickup. If you would prefer shipping (domestic or international) we would be happy to do so! Please contact the gallery for shipping arrangements and fees at info@microscopegallery.com.

[Image above from“Signals” (2013) by Karolina Raczynski, live Skype performance for video projector and handheld mirrors, Microscope Gallery, 2016]

 

Early Bird Alert!

Be among the first 20 to contribute to our campaign at the "Supporter" Level or higher, and receive a special hard enamel pin by Zach Nader of your choice from his series "ghostclocks"!

The Early Bird hard enamel pins from Zach Nader's "ghostclocks" series have all been claimed!

 

 

 

About us

 

 

Microscope Gallery was founded in September of 2010 by artists and curators Andrea Monti and Elle Burchill  in the Bushwick area of Brooklyn, NY as an inclusive space dedicated to the time-based arts, presenting regular exhibitions as well as a weekly series of events featuring emerging to often overlooked, groundbreaking artists.

The main motivations for starting Microscope were to address a general lack of time-based works in art galleries as well as what we considered — and still do — as an unnecessary divide in the conversations and appreciation of works exhibited in the daylight setting of the gallery as opposed to those typically presented in the darkness of the screening/sound/performance venue. 

 

 

Through both exhibitions and events, Microscope offers new and emerging artists the opportunity for larger bodies of their works to be seen, and for rediscoveries of overlooked works by more established artists.  Additionally, Microscope is committed to increasing the inclusivity and diversity of its Series through, among others, a new group of core curators programming events on a regular basis, as well as collaborations with other organizations.

To date, we have presented more than 85 art exhibitions and nearly 600 events featuring works in moving image, digital, sound, performance, and more. Mediums include celluloid film, analog and digital video, stereoscopic 3D, 3D animation; live multi-screen and mixed media performances such as expanded cinema, A/V, 8-bit and VHS mixing; acoustic, noise, spoken word, experimental, and electronic sound; durational and other performance art, among many others.

 

 

We are excited to resume events onsite in our new space as soon as it is safe, and to continue to offer the chance to virtually attend the events online for anyone who is unable to be physically present.

Microscope always welcomes unsolicited submissions of works for consideration in future event and exhibition programming, and reviews them periodically. “Open Call” opportunities each year are also offered.

 

 

 

Microscope Gallery has been featured in many publications in the US and internationally including in Art in America, Artforum, Art Review, BOMB, BreakThruRadio, The Brooklyn Rail, Bushwick Daily, Cinespect, Emergency Index of Performance, Conde Nast Traveler, Huffington Post, Hyperallergic, La Furia Umana, Le Monde, Millennium Film Journal, New York Magazine, Screen Slate, Studio International, The Los Angeles Times, The London Times, The New York Times, The Village Voice, The Wall Street Journal, TIME Magazine, TimeOut NY, Underground Film Journal, Vice, Visionary Film, WYNC, and many others. 

 

 

Why We Need Your Support Now

We have suddenly found ourselves in urgent need of a new home. In the last few weeks, circumstances in our building have made it impossible for us to continue our operations in our current space. As the oldest gallery currently operating in Bushwick for eleven years, we are finding the decision to leave our beloved neighborhood to be an extremely difficult one.

To our surprise, we have quickly managed to find a new space near the High Line in Manhattan that with your help, will allow us to continue and expand our programming. A new location and new home for time-based artists that we hope we will be able to build with your support.

 

 

This includes our Event Series, which requires very specific conditions relating to ceiling height, wall surface space, projection distances, acoustics, equipment storage, and so forth.

Although it may seem optimistic to embark in a move to a new space and to think of the possibility of in-person events during a still ongoing pandemic, it is clear that Microscope cannot exist without a physical place. In the not-too-distant future we will finally be able to reunite again IRL! Also, as we wait for that day, our exhibitions will continue to be on view by appointment only as they have been for the past several months.

 

 

Use of Funds

Between now and our planned opening in late April, there is a lot of work to be done!

By contributing to our Campaign you will help us cover the necessary costs of building and soundproofing walls, electrical and lighting upgrades, as well as upgrades and replacements to our A/V equipment including a new 4k projector and a new projection screen, among others.

 

 

We hope that you will donate to our campaign to make this possible! Special perks are available for each donation level provided by great artists like Peggy Ahwesh, Lea Bertucci, Ben Coonley, Bradley Eros, Marni Kotak, Le’Andra LeSeur, Jonas Mekas / Spector Books,  Zach Nader, Kamron Saniee, and Ray Sweeten.

Please know that a portion of your donation will benefit these artists as well!

 

 

Looking Ahead

Microscope will remain dedicated to artists working with the time-based arts in all their forms and will be guided by the principles of inclusion, equity, and diversity, not only for the artists presented but also for the expanded circle of curators that will be involved on a more regular basis.

Although a lot of work lies ahead before we are able to resume operations and turn the lights off on our first event in a safer world, we are excited about this new chapter for Microscope!

 

 

Perks

Microscope's Tote Bag - 10th Anniversary Edition

For Membership contributions of $80 and above!

 

 

Zach Nader’s “ghostclock #1 and #2”

Hard enamel pins designed by Brooklyn-based artist Zach Nader.

“A ghost that is a clock somewhat warped by time travel.” — ZN

 

 

Sneak Peek Pics!

Contribute $10 or more and we will send you Sneak Peek photos of the new space and updates on the progress!

 

 

Special Video!

A private link to a never-before-seen video of the last performance at the gallery before the shutdown, the groundbreaking light play "Reflektorische Farblichtspiele" by Kurt Schwerdtfeger performed by Tessa Hughes-Freeland, Genevieve Havemeyer-King, Ray Sweeten, and Stephanie Wuertz.

 

 

Lea Bertucci's "A Visible Length of Light"

Released April 2021. Clear 12” Vinyl LP. Edition of 475.

Channelling temperaments of dislocation and wanderlust, filtered through impressions of distinctly American landscapes – coasts, cities, prairie – and the sonic material of everyday experience, defamiliarized by crisis, the New York based composer and multi-instrumentalist, Lea Bertucci, delivers A Visible Length Of Light.

Conceived across much of 2020, A Visible Length is the product of real-time reactions to, and reflections upon, the instability of the year, distilled into a series of prescient auditory typographies that shimmer with life and hope.

Recorded at Bertucci’s home in New York City and in Omaha, Nebraska, during her residency at the Bemis Center for Contemporary Art, A Visible Length Of Light comprises seven condensed works – deploying bass clarinet, alto sax, manipulated tape, organ, a venu wooden flute, and field recordings made in places as wide-ranging as Rio de Janeiro, the California coast, and Dead Horse Bay – surrounded by four “Refrains” – brief, minimal segments that capture Bertucci improvising, via whispers of flute, with the sounds upfolding outside her apartment. Foregoing the long-form compositional approach that has marked her previous albums, it emerges as one of her most pointedly melodic, harmonically rich, and structurally distinct efforts to date.

Credits:

All sounds composed and performed by Lea Bertucci. Recorded by Lea Bertucci. Mixed by Lea Bertucci and Randall Dunn. Mastered by Greg Obis. Cover image by David Benjamin Sherry, Grand Plateau, Grand Staircase - Escalante National Monument, Utah, 2017.  Courtesy of Salon94.

 

 

Kamron Saniee's "Euphoric Studies (SVS017)"

Released March 2021. 12” Vinyl LP. Edition of 300.

Positivity. Lucidity. Velocity. In his second solo release, Kamron Saniee presents six animated studies of concentrated, rhythmic electronica – Euphoric Studies – in search of an "everyday euphoria" for the sunlit hours. 

The works are characterized by a playful yet incisive energy, harkening back to the exuberance of early 2000s post-techno experimentation. Bubbling synthesizer melodies and emergent textural grooves serve to guide listeners towards a lucid, stimulated state. 

Saniee acknowledges his classical influences on the track 'Badinage', in which a theme by Marin Marais played back on the violin is repurposed and diffused into a radiating sonic tapestry. 

On the 10-minute opus 'Rhythm Force', raining percussive elements and drifting, formant harmonies create a prolonged and invigorating environment. The use of overlapping meters in 'Amnion' creates a similarly buoyant energy. 

Credits:

All tracks composed and produced by Kamron Saniee in NYC. Cover illustration by Ryuto Miyake.
Cover image by Margarita Boyarskaya. Design by Paul Putzar. Mastering by Keith Tenniswood. 

 

 

Jonas Mekas' "Scrapbook of the Sixties (Reprint)"

Writings 1958 – 2010. 456 pp. with 100 black/white images, thread-sewn paperback. Leipzig December, 2019. Width: 16 cm. Length: 21.5 cm. Language(s): English.

Andy Warhol, Susan Sontag, John Lennon & Yoko Ono — Jonas Mekas was well acquainted with a great many New York artists. Born in Lithuania, he came to Brooklyn via Germany in 1949 and began shooting his first experimental films there. Mekas developed a form of film diary in which he recorded his daily observations. He became the barometer of the New York art scene and a pioneer of American avant-garde cinema. Every week, starting in 1958 he published his legendary »Movie Journal« column in the Village Voice, writing on a range of subjects that were by no means restricted to the world of film. He conducted numerous interviews with artists, some of which will now appear for the first time in his Scrapbook of a Sixties. The book contains published and unpublished texts that reveal Mekas as a thoughtful diarist and an unparalleled chronicler of the day — a phenomenon that has continued now for over fifty years. — Spector Books

Includes: Jonas Mekas in conversation with Erick Hawkins and Lucia Dlugoszewski, Judith Malina and Julian Beck (The Living Theatre), Pier Paolo Pasolini, Richard Foreman, Susan Sontag, Hermann Nitsch, Peter Kubelka, Nam June Paik, John Lennon & Yoko Ono

EDITOR:Anne König. DESIGNER: Fabian Bremer, Pascal Storz.

 

 

Peggy Ahwesh's "Beirut: Channel Surfing" (2021)

Inkjet archival print, 8 x 10 inches (20.3 x 25.4 cm), edition of 100, signed on verso

A new print work by Peggy Ahwesh featuring a collection of images from popular TV shows as shot by the artist off of a TV screen through channel surfing while in Beirut, Lebanon in 2006. The framing of each image within the file preview window adds to the sense of a database or an inventory in formation, with media samples extracted from the constant flow of broadcast.

 

 

Marni Kotak's "Love Mask" (2020)

Custom designed and photo printed fabric, 100% tightly knit cotton, machine washable
Size: 5 x 7 inches, with elastic to fit behind ears. Edition of 50.

Organic cotton sateen mask sewn by artist Marni Kotak made as a result of an ongoing performance. The mask features the word “Love” embedded in a lotus flower, which Kotak explains as a reference to the symbol of the lotus in Buddhism, symbolizing the beauty that emerges from the muck, or deepest challenges in life. The image is based on a pastel drawing by the artist. This mask in its “original” design by the artist is a limited edition of 50. Each mask comes with Certificate of Authenticity signed by the artist.

 

 

Bradley Eros' "Silver Plane" (2021)

Aluminum, dimensions variable. Includes a video tutorial in which Eros demonstrates how to fly the plane.

Bradley Eros’ planes in paper and other materials debuted at his solo exhibition "All that is solid melts into eros" at the gallery in 2018. The planes, referencing the natural element of “air,” in the show were arranged on a table and the audience was encouraged to fly them towards a black painted area on the wall. Ini these works — made with a nod to Harry Smith — the ephemeral is considered as an alternative to the traditional assumptions, models, and struggles for the everlasting life of the work of art.

 

 

Ben Coonley's "Cardboard" (2020)

1500 piece jigsaw puzzle, 31 1/2 x 23 1/2 inches, edition of 50

A challenging 1500-piece jigsaw puzzle by Ben Coonley’s portraying his long-time friend and collaborator Otto (the cat) absorbed in solving a puzzle!

 

 

Ray Sweeten's "MSTAPES:1987-2021" (2021)

60 minute audio cassette. Edition of 20.

A collection of sound recordings by Ray Sweeten spanning 34 years, utilizing an evolving set of recording technology and electronic instruments, from consumer-grade dual cassette machines and department store keyboards, vintage samplers and FM modules to Bucchla 200 systems and 8-track ADAT recorders, to modern Eurorack and the digital DAW. The newer recordings from this year (2021) were made with sounds and samples produced between 1990-2003. Many of the original documents of the older recordings have been lost, so the sound quality reflects the medium of the surviving recordings. MSTAPES was produced as a small batch run of 20 cassettes in the artist’s home studio using the same tape machine used for some of the original recordings.

 

 

Le’Andra LeSeur's "And in the same breath…" (2020)

Inkjet and Archival Ink on Linen Paper, 11 x 8.5 inches, edition of 10, signed by the artist.

"And in the same breath..." explores the agency black women hold over their own existence and the fight we make in continuously uplifting our own voices. As an artist who primarily works within video, I am continuously thinking about the ways in which we intake an image, whether moving or static, accompanied by language. Over the past six years, we’ve seen an influx of shared content exposing the violence inflicted on black bodies. These videos have become so incessant and pervasive that it has made me question my own existence as a black queer woman amidst this struggle.

In each instance, I’ve noticed how overwhelming language can become after experiencing an act of violence. In an attempt to get back to a place of healing and self-love, I’ve had to embrace silence, and allow my thoughts to be present and fully honored. From this silence, I’ve created new language that has allowed me to speak—directly from the heart and freely without any concern or fear of judgment. — LL
story_txt:
Microscope must unexpectedly move from its long-time space in Bushwick Brooklyn by the end of April. We are seeking your help to create a new home that will allow us to continue and expand our programming, especially our weekly Event Series of time-based arts, which we have been preparing to resume in-person — after more than a year online — as soon as it is safely possible.
Your support will help us transform the new space we have found near the High Line in Manhattan to house our now 10 1/2 year-long Event Series that includes screenings of all formats (film, analog & digital video, etc.) music and experimental sound nights, performance art, expanded cinema, poetry, artist talks and more.
Although it has been a difficult decision to leave our current space and neighborhood, we are excited about this new chapter for Microscope and hope that you will contribute to make this transition possible!
For those who would like tax-deductible options please visit our companion campaign on Fractured Atlas HERE.
The total amount we must raise through both campaigns is $30,000.
 
Please Note: All perks will be available at the gallery for local pickup. If you would prefer shipping (domestic or international) we would be happy to do so! Please contact the gallery for shipping arrangements and fees at info@microscopegallery.com.
[Image above from“Signals” (2013) by Karolina Raczynski, live Skype performance for video projector and handheld mirrors, Microscope Gallery, 2016]
 
Early Bird Alert!
Be among the first 20 to contribute to our campaign at the "Supporter" Level or higher, and receive a special hard enamel pin by Zach Nader of your choice from his series "ghostclocks"!

The Early Bird hard enamel pins from Zach Nader's "ghostclocks" series have all been claimed!
 
 
 
About us
 

 
Microscope Gallery was founded in September of 2010 by artists and curators Andrea Monti and Elle Burchill  in the Bushwick area of Brooklyn, NY as an inclusive space dedicated to the time-based arts, presenting regular exhibitions as well as a weekly series of events featuring emerging to often overlooked, groundbreaking artists.
The main motivations for starting Microscope were to address a general lack of time-based works in art galleries as well as what we considered — and still do — as an unnecessary divide in the conversations and appreciation of works exhibited in the daylight setting of the gallery as opposed to those typically presented in the darkness of the screening/sound/performance venue. 
 

 
Through both exhibitions and events, Microscope offers new and emerging artists the opportunity for larger bodies of their works to be seen, and for rediscoveries of overlooked works by more established artists.  Additionally, Microscope is committed to increasing the inclusivity and diversity of its Series through, among others, a new group of core curators programming events on a regular basis, as well as collaborations with other organizations.
To date, we have presented more than 85 art exhibitions and nearly 600 events featuring works in moving image, digital, sound, performance, and more. Mediums include celluloid film, analog and digital video, stereoscopic 3D, 3D animation; live multi-screen and mixed media performances such as expanded cinema, A/V, 8-bit and VHS mixing; acoustic, noise, spoken word, experimental, and electronic sound; durational and other performance art, among many others.
 

 
We are excited to resume events onsite in our new space as soon as it is safe, and to continue to offer the chance to virtually attend the events online for anyone who is unable to be physically present.
Microscope always welcomes unsolicited submissions of works for consideration in future event and exhibition programming, and reviews them periodically. “Open Call” opportunities each year are also offered.
 
 

 
Microscope Gallery has been featured in many publications in the US and internationally including in Art in America, Artforum, Art Review, BOMB, BreakThruRadio, The Brooklyn Rail, Bushwick Daily, Cinespect, Emergency Index of Performance, Conde Nast Traveler, Huffington Post, Hyperallergic, La Furia Umana, Le Monde, Millennium Film Journal, New York Magazine, Screen Slate, Studio International, The Los Angeles Times, The London Times, The New York Times, The Village Voice, The Wall Street Journal, TIME Magazine, TimeOut NY, Underground Film Journal, Vice, Visionary Film, WYNC, and many others. 
 
 

Why We Need Your Support Now
We have suddenly found ourselves in urgent need of a new home. In the last few weeks, circumstances in our building have made it impossible for us to continue our operations in our current space. As the oldest gallery currently operating in Bushwick for eleven years, we are finding the decision to leave our beloved neighborhood to be an extremely difficult one.
To our surprise, we have quickly managed to find a new space near the High Line in Manhattan that with your help, will allow us to continue and expand our programming. A new location and new home for time-based artists that we hope we will be able to build with your support.
 

 
This includes our Event Series, which requires very specific conditions relating to ceiling height, wall surface space, projection distances, acoustics, equipment storage, and so forth.
Although it may seem optimistic to embark in a move to a new space and to think of the possibility of in-person events during a still ongoing pandemic, it is clear that Microscope cannot exist without a physical place. In the not-too-distant future we will finally be able to reunite again IRL! Also, as we wait for that day, our exhibitions will continue to be on view by appointment only as they have been for the past several months.
 
 

Use of Funds
Between now and our planned opening in late April, there is a lot of work to be done!
By contributing to our Campaign you will help us cover the necessary costs of building and soundproofing walls, electrical and lighting upgrades, as well as upgrades and replacements to our A/V equipment including a new 4k projector and a new projection screen, among others.
 

 
We hope that you will donate to our campaign to make this possible! Special perks are available for each donation level provided by great artists like Peggy Ahwesh, Lea Bertucci, Ben Coonley, Bradley Eros, Marni Kotak, Le’Andra LeSeur, Jonas Mekas / Spector Books,  Zach Nader, Kamron Saniee, and Ray Sweeten.
Please know that a portion of your donation will benefit these artists as well!
 
 

Looking Ahead
Microscope will remain dedicated to artists working with the time-based arts in all their forms and will be guided by the principles of inclusion, equity, and diversity, not only for the artists presented but also for the expanded circle of curators that will be involved on a more regular basis.
Although a lot of work lies ahead before we are able to resume operations and turn the lights off on our first event in a safer world, we are excited about this new chapter for Microscope!

 
 
Perks

Microscope's Tote Bag - 10th Anniversary Edition
For Membership contributions of $80 and above!
 
 

Zach Nader’s “ghostclock #1 and #2”
Hard enamel pins designed by Brooklyn-based artist Zach Nader.
“A ghost that is a clock somewhat warped by time travel.” — ZN
 
 

Sneak Peek Pics!
Contribute $10 or more and we will send you Sneak Peek photos of the new space and updates on the progress!
 
 

Special Video!
A private link to a never-before-seen video of the last performance at the gallery before the shutdown, the groundbreaking light play "Reflektorische Farblichtspiele" by Kurt Schwerdtfeger performed by Tessa Hughes-Freeland, Genevieve Havemeyer-King, Ray Sweeten, and Stephanie Wuertz.
 
 

Lea Bertucci's "A Visible Length of Light"
Released April 2021. Clear 12” Vinyl LP. Edition of 475.
Channelling temperaments of dislocation and wanderlust, filtered through impressions of distinctly American landscapes – coasts, cities, prairie – and the sonic material of everyday experience, defamiliarized by crisis, the New York based composer and multi-instrumentalist, Lea Bertucci, delivers A Visible Length Of Light.
Conceived across much of 2020, A Visible Length is the product of real-time reactions to, and reflections upon, the instability of the year, distilled into a series of prescient auditory typographies that shimmer with life and hope.
Recorded at Bertucci’s home in New York City and in Omaha, Nebraska, during her residency at the Bemis Center for Contemporary Art, A Visible Length Of Light comprises seven condensed works – deploying bass clarinet, alto sax, manipulated tape, organ, a venu wooden flute, and field recordings made in places as wide-ranging as Rio de Janeiro, the California coast, and Dead Horse Bay – surrounded by four “Refrains” – brief, minimal segments that capture Bertucci improvising, via whispers of flute, with the sounds upfolding outside her apartment. Foregoing the long-form compositional approach that has marked her previous albums, it emerges as one of her most pointedly melodic, harmonically rich, and structurally distinct efforts to date.
Credits:
All sounds composed and performed by Lea Bertucci. Recorded by Lea Bertucci. Mixed by Lea Bertucci and Randall Dunn. Mastered by Greg Obis. Cover image by David Benjamin Sherry, Grand Plateau, Grand Staircase - Escalante National Monument, Utah, 2017.  Courtesy of Salon94.
 
 

Kamron Saniee's "Euphoric Studies (SVS017)"
Released March 2021. 12” Vinyl LP. Edition of 300.
Positivity. Lucidity. Velocity. In his second solo release, Kamron Saniee presents six animated studies of concentrated, rhythmic electronica – Euphoric Studies – in search of an "everyday euphoria" for the sunlit hours. 
The works are characterized by a playful yet incisive energy, harkening back to the exuberance of early 2000s post-techno experimentation. Bubbling synthesizer melodies and emergent textural grooves serve to guide listeners towards a lucid, stimulated state. 
Saniee acknowledges his classical influences on the track 'Badinage', in which a theme by Marin Marais played back on the violin is repurposed and diffused into a radiating sonic tapestry. 
On the 10-minute opus 'Rhythm Force', raining percussive elements and drifting, formant harmonies create a prolonged and invigorating environment. The use of overlapping meters in 'Amnion' creates a similarly buoyant energy. 
Credits:
All tracks composed and produced by Kamron Saniee in NYC. Cover illustration by Ryuto Miyake.Cover image by Margarita Boyarskaya. Design by Paul Putzar. Mastering by Keith Tenniswood. 
 
 

Jonas Mekas' "Scrapbook of the Sixties (Reprint)"
Writings 1958 – 2010. 456 pp. with 100 black/white images, thread-sewn paperback. Leipzig December, 2019. Width: 16 cm. Length: 21.5 cm. Language(s): English.
Andy Warhol, Susan Sontag, John Lennon & Yoko Ono — Jonas Mekas was well acquainted with a great many New York artists. Born in Lithuania, he came to Brooklyn via Germany in 1949 and began shooting his first experimental films there. Mekas developed a form of film diary in which he recorded his daily observations. He became the barometer of the New York art scene and a pioneer of American avant-garde cinema. Every week, starting in 1958 he published his legendary »Movie Journal« column in the Village Voice, writing on a range of subjects that were by no means restricted to the world of film. He conducted numerous interviews with artists, some of which will now appear for the first time in his Scrapbook of a Sixties. The book contains published and unpublished texts that reveal Mekas as a thoughtful diarist and an unparalleled chronicler of the day — a phenomenon that has continued now for over fifty years. — Spector Books
Includes: Jonas Mekas in conversation with Erick Hawkins and Lucia Dlugoszewski, Judith Malina and Julian Beck (The Living Theatre), Pier Paolo Pasolini, Richard Foreman, Susan Sontag, Hermann Nitsch, Peter Kubelka, Nam June Paik, John Lennon & Yoko Ono
EDITOR:Anne König. DESIGNER: Fabian Bremer, Pascal Storz.
 
 

Peggy Ahwesh's "Beirut: Channel Surfing" (2021)
Inkjet archival print, 8 x 10 inches (20.3 x 25.4 cm), edition of 100, signed on verso
A new print work by Peggy Ahwesh featuring a collection of images from popular TV shows as shot by the artist off of a TV screen through channel surfing while in Beirut, Lebanon in 2006. The framing of each image within the file preview window adds to the sense of a database or an inventory in formation, with media samples extracted from the constant flow of broadcast.

A challenging 1500-piece jigsaw puzzle by Ben Coonley’s portraying his long-time friend and collaborator Otto (the cat) absorbed in solving a puzzle!

story:
Skin City Body Painting is taking radical body acceptance to a whole new level as people of all shapes and sizes come together to body paint each other in the name of EQUALITY, diversity and promoting positive body-image.

This historic event is taking place in the parking lot outside Skin City at Downtown Spaces, in the heart of the Las Vegas Arts District.  It is free and open to anyone who registers on Skin City's facebook event page. This art happening will be filmed by the award-winning Light Forge Studios, bringing a day of fun and a message of equality to a global audience through the finished video.

It will be filmed from the ground and the sky, as multiple bodies come together to form a giant = sign.

Your support will pay for all aspects of the event, including the following:

+ Location rental

+ Camera crew and equipment rental

+ 24 gallons of body paint

+ Project materials & equipment: rollers, brushes, dropcloths, rags, tape etc

+ Promotional materials

+ Lunch, drinks and snacks to keep everyone hydrated and happy

+ Video editing

Please contribute to our project and help spread equality and acceptance across these bodies and across the planet. Thank you!

story:
Thank you for stopping to look at my campaign.

My name is Chris Ryan and my passion is my business, Pandora’s Closet. It’s a one woman sewing business focusing on creating clothing and costuming that comes out of dreams and imagination. Both mine, and my clients. I create everything from wedding dresses to steampunk super heroes to historically accurate garments from just about any period.

I have been designing and sewing for 17 years and have been steadily working to build Pandora’s Closet as a business for the last 6. It has been one of my missions in this endeavor not to dig myself and my business into debt and to build the business only on its profits. But now I have run into an investment that I need help with.

I have long married embroidery into my designs as it adds something special to each garment that it is added to. I have been blessed that my mother, Deborah Larson, is an award winning digitizer who can pretty much turn anything I think of into the ones and zeros that allow an embroidery machine to do it’s magic. It’s truly an art form all its own. What I am lacking is an embroidery machine. Up to this point she has been a saint and has taken my piles of fabric and sewn them out on her sample machine. It has worked up to this point, but it is a lot of extra travel back and forth for the fabric and a huge amount of her time that could be spent creating new designs. The time has come for me to get a machine of my own.

That’s where you come in, helping my dreams of taking my business to the next level come true by assisting me in getting a Bernina E16, industrial embroidery machine. The total cost of the machine is well outside of my current ability to make the purchase on my own without taking on a large debt. I am confident that once I have the machine incorporated into my business that the level of my designs and the creativity that I will be able to express will make the investment one that is invaluable in allowing me to make Pandora’s Closet my full time job and to let me leave my day job.

What I Need & What You Get

In order to make this dream a reality I am looking for the following funding.

The Bernina E16 itself costs $16,000. I would like to purchase two years of maintenance upfront in order to insure the lifetime usability of this investment. Along with this machine I will need to purchase the stabilizers and backings, threads and bobbins to be able to start embroidering right away. What good is the machine if you can’t sew anything?!? Also there are fees involved in running a campaign such as this and those are included in my overall goal.

If for any reason I do not make my full funding goal I will use the funds to place a large down payment on the machine to keep the amount of debt for my business to a minimum. So every penny will help me achieve my goal!

I am very excited because almost all of my perks will include beautiful embroidery! Everything from hand towels for the unique at hear to full custom clothing with beautiful designs gracing them.

Perks:

$1 Thank you!

$5 Thank you on website and my Pandora’s Closet facebook.

$20 Random Pinup 5x7 postcard of Pandora through the ages

$20 Ode to you on my Pandora’s Closet facebook page.

$50 Random 3 Pandora through the ages Pinup 5x7 postcards

$50 pair of custom embroidered hand or kitchen towels

$75 Heraldic animal embroidered onto a period pouch.

$75 Full set of 5 Pandora through the ages  5x7 postcards.

$100 choice of blackwork embroidered men's shirt or ladies partlet/blouse

$100 Custom Embroidered geek t-shirt

$200 choice of black velvet embroidered knotwork doublet or bodice

$200 custom embroidered Poison Ivy/ Harley hoodie or Joker/Batman hoodie

$500 your choice of complete custom embroidered men's or women's middle class renaissance outfit. Women's outfit to include bloomers, embroidered blouse, Embroidered bodice, 2 skirts and hat. Men's outfit to include Embroidered shirt, embroidered doublet, pants, hat and hooded mantel or half cape.

$500 Custom embroidered hooded cloak or Highwayman's style men's or women's coat.

$1000 Full custom Steampunk super hero costume designed specifically for you.

$1500 full custom embroidered men's or women's complete Tudor/Elizabethan court outfit. Men's outfit to include pants/slops, shirt, doublet, greatcoat/half cape and hat. Ladies ensemble to include forepart, overskirt, partlet, bodice/sleeves and hat.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t contribute to my campaign monetarily, it would mean the world to me if you would get the word out about my dream! Please share, post, tweet, Instagram, email and shout from the rooftops about helping a a gal with big dreams realize one of them!

story:
CASTLE CONEJO

We are Medieval re-enactors and Medieval history buffs. It shows, huh? We are building our own home in the shape of a castle. We are members of the Society for Creative Anachronism, a group whose purpose is to keep alive medieval crafts, pastimes, and Arts. http://www.welcome.sca.org . This site will tell you all about what we do, and there's a chapter in every state! (That's our border collie in the window.)

What We use it for:

Castle Conejo ( "Conejo" is Spanish for rabbit, by the way - we live on Conejo St.) is more than just our dwelling. First, it's a  showpiece- It's made of "Perform Wall" blocks, building material that we're trying to tell everyone about! We like showing people that you CAN build your own home, with less money, education and contractor help than you think. Please check out their link! http://www.efbm.com

Also, the Castle is a Workshop- we open our shop to people who are working on their own (mostly medieval) Arts, Crafts and home projects. The Castle is our business workshop as well. Please check us out at http://www.danddmetalart.com 

We hope to some day make the Castle a Living History site, with some "hands on" projects people can do.

What we're Wishing for:

We're building the Castle "out of pocket", as we can afford it- without taking out any loans, so it's been as primitive as a real castle at times. $50,000 would completely finish the building, inside and out, and get the few tools in the shop that we don't already have! (This photo is a front view of the building - the back half isn't nearly this finished!)

 It would also furnish those 2 guest bedrooms upstairs. We live way out in the desert- when people come to work on their art and projects, they like to stay a day or two. We have a dream of making this a workshop-themed Bed-and-Breakfast Inn some day!  

  If you can help out financially, our resident Artist, DION, will handcraft an item or items for you that we think you will be proud to own. You can brag that your piece was made in a castle! Again, please check out DION's web and facebook page, and spread the word about his labors of love. 


 Challenges:

We've been financing this completely by ourselves, although a LOT of the labor has been done by friends and acquaintances. Like so many other Americans, we recently both became unemployed, and we hate to see this dream postponed til "who knows when"!


Other Ways You Can Help:

Believe me, I know how tight money is! You'll be helping if you will point other people to INDIEGOGO, and our campaign. You'll help "THE DREAM", and maybe find yourself a rewarding hobby by checking out  www.welcome.sca.org and join the fun!
story_txt:
CASTLE CONEJO We are Medieval re-enactors and Medieval history buffs. It shows, huh? We are building our own home in the shape of a castle. We are members of the Society for Creative Anachronism, a group whose purpose is to keep alive medieval crafts, pastimes, and Arts. http://www.welcome.sca.org . This site will tell you all about what we do, and there's a chapter in every state! (That's our border collie in the window.)   What We use it for:

Castle Conejo ( "Conejo" is Spanish for rabbit, by the way - we live on Conejo St.) is more than just our dwelling. First, it's a  showpiece- It's made of "Perform Wall" blocks, building material that we're trying to tell everyone about! We like showing people that you CAN build your own home, with less money, education and contractor help than you think. Please check out their link! http://www.efbm.com
