story:
What is The Future of Arts?

This is the question we raised in the last ten days.
It's also the name of the community we started growing, of artists and art-lovers alike.

We looked at the present to explore what the future of arts and design could look like, and if there will even be a future.
We came to the conclusion, that, yes maybe the arts are at risk.
We came to change it.

Why is that?

The main aspect putting the arts in danger is the way the art markets work.

Admittedly, the striking majority of talents out there will probably never be confronted with the art markets, because they give up or give in long before they could get a chance to. And that is the first part of what is going wrong. How much earth-shattering, life-altering and history-changing art is not happening right now, because the artist behind is too busy waitressing in order to get their rent earned?

Sadly, we'll never know.

What we do know though, is what happens to those who try and make an artistic career.

We'd like to give you the short version here, if you're more into detail, you can find it in this video (or just go on with the text if you love shortcuts):


Putting out artistic products can be a complex matter. Art needs to be produced and reproduced, often it will be published and promoted and you might want to organize live events or exhibitions. Obviously this all depends on the nature of the art itself, but one thing is true for all: You want to live off that art, you got to make money out of it. It's not romantic, but we all need to pay our bills. Can't live off applause and love alone. Can't work two full time jobs forever.

Now if you, as an artist, want to go pro, you need people to do those jobs for you. Obviously, you could try on your own. But in the end you'll, again, be more busy managing stuff in order to get your rent earned than you'll actually be making arts. So you turn to companies who are supposed to produce, publish, promote, distribute and sell your artistic products and manage your career. You make a gazillion contracts, some may get you financial advances, you quickly loose overview, but you consider yourself lucky. After all, you're career is looked after and you can concentrate on making art now, right?

The crooked part about this is the fact that you are bound by contracts and financial debts now, which put you under immense pressure to score a success with every piece of art you decide to publish. Your art became a product, and you got to live up to that expectation. If you don't, chances are you will be kicked out of your contracts long before they end - leaving you behind with nothing but a pile of dust to clean up. You yourself however have no way of dropping out. And even as long as you're in your contracts, the bad part is that you might be earning something, but it is just a fraction of the money your art pays off. If you're lucky, you see 10% of your revenues - if you're not, it might be less than 1%.


How are we going to change this?

We are musicians. We've been here, trying to get our foot into this industry for a long period of time. Good luck for us, we ended up in promotion dayjobs, and one of us got the chance to work in distribution for THE major headphone brand - and therefore learn of the pros.

We have also stumbled upon the fact that in many industries, it's a normal thing that small businesses and businessmen get together and form a society. They do that to be able to acquire bigger jobs and customers or to have a better basis of negotiation when making contracts with buyers or distributors. They stay independent and flexible, but they can compete with industry giants and be more succesful with less effort. It's a smart model which works out great for many.

It's normal in so many industries, why isn't it when it comes to arts?

Of all people, artists really would want to have a network they can rely on with their career, yet stay independent and in full control of their own artistic decisions.

We asked ourselves: Why does no one DO this thing?

And we realised: We got the passion, we got the knowledge, why don't we just start!

In our model, artists join the network we started. Together, they run a company that takes over all the complex jobs with managing, distribution, publishing or promotion. They get a direct payout of 60% of everything they earn. The other 40% are kept to hire staff and nurture new talent. At the end of each business year, the profit is split evenly between all artists and everyone gets a dividend - and therefore everyone benefits from the overall success of the company. There is no kicking anyone out of contracts because they don't live up to artificially inflated expectations. If someone wants to leave, they just do it.


Recap


Why Us?

We think you can totally trust in us being the right people to get this project done. Here's five reasons why:


Where We Are & What We Need

We have set up key account distribution for all kinds of artistic products, we have all nessecary structures in place to get this thing rolling and our own online shop in the making. We started with a marketing campaign ten days prior to this Indiegogo campaign, and received great response. We got the first artists joining our network. The hurdle in our way is the fact that artistic and creative projects need their time to take off - and pay off. With this campaign, we are raising the funds to keep us going for six months - if we exceed our goal, we will be going even longer without having to worry about how to cover costs. Let's not let the future end before it began!

Our goal is 50.000$ - they get us going for six months. Our expenses split up as followed:

  • 19.500$ - One fulltime or two parttime hands to support us for six months
  • 11.500$ - Computers, software, promotion materials and furniture which is all desperately needed
  • 6.800$ - Rent for our business property for six months
  • 6.800$ - A car, fuel and insurance to keep us mobile for six months
  • 3.500$ - A little reserve for sudden emergencies to make sure we don't slip 
  • 1.900$ - Indiegogo Fees

If we don't manage to meet 50.000$, we are still continuing with this project. Every dollar you give is invested wisely and won't be lost, it would mean though that things would go a lot slower.


What You Get

Every contribution is welcome. Choose one of our amazing perks in return!

(Note for non-EU inhabitants: Please add 10$ to your perk for international shipping. Thank you!)

These are the designs used on our T-Shirts:


Membership System

If you want to support us regularly and receive great treats in advance, we have a membership system ready for you to enjoy!

Have a look and compare our Patron Memberships with one quick glance:


    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you like what we're doing here, there's many ways you can help other than contributing financially. It's crucial that our idea is spread as far as possible, and we're sure that all of you know like-minded art-lovers and artists. Please help us spread the word, like and share our profiles on Facebook, Google+, Twitter, Tumblr, Instagram, YouTube and Pinterest, spread our videos, spread the word, love art, make art and get involved! Thank You!

    UPDATE: Want to give but can't contribute money? Lend your voice to us and donate your social followers to the cause! It takes less than a minute and you can use your existing Facebook, Twitter or Tumblr account: Join us on Thunderclap.

story:
Creation of a new body of Paintings on History and Nature  

Living and working between Paris , London and New York ,  sharing  my view on the world and the arts throughout my films,  I now propose my new series which I hope gets your attention!

After my experience filmmaking

(« Replay again», « Alphalane Avenue »), 

my documentaries  (« Imagining peace ») filmed in  Costa Rica about the Peace University , "Topanga" on a  artist community in Malibu , California , 

my Artists portraits videos "Intersections : New York " , 

my Art Videos "Night and day" , "Ultra Violet pop Artist" muse of Andy Warhol and Salvador Dali (Kampa Museum ,Prague, 2006)  ... my paintings … 

and the project "Birds without sky , Requiem for the mad " by Victoria Neel 

which led to my series of acrylic paintings, on small canvas, dedicated to my Animals series  " Fantastic Animals , Owls and Company " I am starting a new series of twenty  paintings exploring the large themes of History and Nature.

The project reflects the vision of a dream world where historical figures are juxtaposed and adapted to contemporary fantasies 

The paintings will be playful , lyrical , joyous .

Drawing on paper Cheval Ailé Mythe de Pégase. 8,3x11,7 inches 


This project is very important , and it needs your support . This new painting production will be seen in a gallery  during the first semester of 2016 , and this evolution , this progression is vital .  


En Français 
Entre Paris, Londres et New York, je vous propose depuis plusieurs années de partager mon regard sur le monde et les arts à travers mes films 
(« Replay again», « Alphalane Avenue »), 
mes documentaires (« Imagining peace ») réalisé au Costa Rica sur l' Université de la Paix , "Topanga" sur une communauté d' Artistes de Californie 
 mes portraits vidéo d’artistes « Intersections: New York »
mes vidéos d’art « Night and day » (présenté à Diva Art fair, NYC ) et "Ultra Violet Pop Artist" muse de Andy Warhol et Salvador Dali (Kampa Museum,Prague,  2006) ...et mes peintures petits et grands formats  .
 Sans oublier le projet « Les Oiseaux sans ciel, requiem des Fous » de l'artiste Victoria Neel auquel je collabore depuis plusieurs années. 

  Après une série de peintures, sur de petits formats acryliques, consacrée à mon bestiaire "Animaux fantastiques, Chouettes et Compagnie"  je me lance dans la réalisation d'une nouvelle série de 20 peintures acryliques consacrée... à l'Histoire et à la Nature.

  Mon nouveau projet stimule toute mes  énergies et suscitera, j'espère, votre intérêt ! 

Un projet sur une vision d'un monde onirique où se juxtaposent des personnages historiques, idéalisés à des fantaisies contemporaines , un projet plein de fantaisie et de bonne humeur .

C est un projet qui me tient à coeur et qui a besoin de votre soutien. Cette nouvelle production de peintures aura vocation à être présentée dans une galerie au premier semestre 2016 et cette évolution, cette progression est vitale.

Acrylic painting 30x40 cm 


et mon blog www.benedictegauthier.blogspot.com



Watercolor 8,3x11,7 inches 


BESOINS 

Le budget de cette nouvelle production est évalué à  8.000 euros ceci pour l'achat de toiles, cadres, peintures et pour le transport des oeuvres. C'est un budget qui me parait raisonnable afin d organiser ma prochaine exposition, et mettre en place trois mois de production. 

Needs

The budget for this new production is evaluated to 8.000 euros , to buy all the materials , transportation , and the three months production .

Be generous, and 5% will go to this great Foundation

http://www.wwf.fr/

and 5% will go to Mona Bismarck American centre for Art and Culture

http://www.monabismarck.org/?lang=fr

Once the works are completed I will give 5% of the future sales to the foundation WWF  of any of the paintings that are funded , and 5% to the Mona Bismarck center 


MY MAJOR SHOWCASES :   Kampa museum (Prague, Czech republic); Anthology Films Archives (New York); Diva Digital and Video Art Fair (New York and Paris); Lubéron Television (France); Scope Art Fair (New York /London); Ultra Studio (New York); Ecole des Beaux-Arts de Marseille; Galerie des Anges (Paris); Connections by LE BOOK (London, NY); Cannes Film Fest (Cannes, France) MonkeyTown exhibitions Space (Brooklyn, NY); Pink TV ; MNN ; Perpetual Art Machine Pool Art Fair (NY); Alliance Française  (NY); Metalstone Gallery (NY); The Harlem Art Project (NY,  Saatchi & Saatchi); CAVE (NY); Bauhaus 196 (NY) ; Westbeth Gallery (NY); The Watermill Center (Long Island, NY)


 Art Galleries 

  • Show At Galerie Des Anges, Paris, (2000) 
  •  Works on paper with Pastels and Indian Ink 
  • Residency at the Watermill CenterLong Island (2007) : documenting by Film and Pictures a Butoh Dance team (contemporary Japanese dancers)  , 
  • Opening for "Room Service " (2007) : 9 Paintings serie, 284 Lafayette  at a private place (canvas depicting Hotel room scenes - a film shoot, a Rock party, circus people, a lonely guy). 
  • One month paintings show  at  the Art space BREAD, Nolita , NYC. (2007). 
  • Gallery 21 Perham road , London 2013 
  • "Animaux fantastiques, Chouettes et Compagnie". JB Galerie (Paris) 2014

*My paintings are part of various collections internationally  Fabio  (London ) John  Lave (LA)  John Colbat (Paris) ,   Larry Wilson (Houston Tx) , James Fitz (New York)…..Tom (Paris)  ,The Harlem art project   and numerous private collections.


Mona  .. Pastel on paper ..8,3x11,7 inches 


  • Ici quelques liens Vidéos / Here some links to my Videos
  • INTERSECTIONS : NEW YORK part 1 
  • http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q1JcB-mCvtE
  • INTERSECTIONS : NEW YORK part 2
  • http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S3O3kZGh0MU
  • INTERSECTIONS : NEW YORK part 3
  • http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HXjuVYVVIp
  • IMAGINING PEACE 
  • http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x4aj3q_imagining-peace_news
  • ALPHALANE AVENUE MUSIC VIDEO 
  • https://vimeo.com/56286045
  • "BEN" By TRAVIS BURKI ; MUSIC VIDEO 
  • http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=miZiKr48wwI
  • TOPANGA 
  • http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x4pbjf_topanga1stpart_creation#.UUWe_1utqWQ
  • ULTRA VIOLET 
  • http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x4i4ji_ultravioletshort_creation#.UUWf5VutqWQ
  • Random Access Poetics ,Film featuring Lee Wells , Chris Borkowski and Jeremy Slater
  • http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x4i7yf_random-access-poetics_creation

Opening for "Room Service " (2007) : 9 Paintings serie, 284 Lafayette  at a private place (canvas depicting Hotel room scenes - a film shoot, a Rock party, circus people, a lonely guy). 
One month paintings show  at  the Art space BREAD, Nolita , NYC. (2007). 
Gallery 21 Perham road , London 2013 
"Animaux fantastiques, Chouettes et Compagnie". JB Galerie (Paris) 2014
*My paintings are part of various collections internationally  Fabio  (London ) John  Lave (LA)  John Colbat (Paris) ,   Larry Wilson (Houston Tx) , James Fitz (New York)…..Tom (Paris)  ,The Harlem art project   and numerous private collections.



Mona  .. Pastel on paper ..8,3x11,7 inches

story:
About Simon Fire Edition

Potluck is making a second edition of their popular interactive fire sculpture, and needs your help to complete it and bring it to Burning Man!

Simon Fire Edition 2.0 is the electronic game you played as a kid, writ large and set on fire. Simon features a large laser cut, touch-sensitive console that allows participants to play the classic memory game. Of course, while that's happening, four large towers surrounding the players light up with 1500 LEDs each and pump out classic sound effects. And if your memory is good enough, you're rewarded with huge fireballs!

Simon Fire Edition 2.0 represents the culmination of years of work for our artists. We've spent years honing our skills on other art projects we've brought to Burning Man, and this is our biggest project yet.

We will be bringing Simon Fire Edition 2.0 to Burning Man 2015, where the 60,000 participants will get a change to play with it each night (and we hope this means you).  We will also be bringing Simon to Critical Northwest, the Pacific Northwest's regional burn.

About the team

Potluck is a group of artists, engineers, and digital troublemakers based in Seattle who have been working to bring art to both Burning Man and regional events since 2009.

The team behind this project has contributed to several placed Burning Man art projects: 2010’s Arborealis, 2011’s Lake Lahontan Point, 2012’s Nozomi, and 2013’s Ablation Cascade. A smaller iteration of Simon was also brought as an in-camp project in 2013. The team behind Simon Fire Edition 2.0  has the knowledge, experience, and enthusiasm to bring this project to the playa for 2015.

Simon Fire Edition 1.0

Simon Fire Edition 1.0 is, of course, the precursor to Simon 2.0. The first Simon followed the same idea: take a classic game, and add lights, fire, and sound effects. Unlike Simon 2.0, Simon 1.0 featured a single tower with four individually animated light panels and a single propane poofer. The first Simon also featured an original Simon game from the '70s hacked and re-purposed into a custom controller for Simon Fire Edition.

Simon Fire Edition 1.0 is where the team really refined the skills that are going into building and delivering 2.0. On Simon 1.0, we cut our teeth on wireless communications, building scary (but safe) fire effects, and more.

Simon Fire Edition 1.0 was featured at Critical Northwest 2013, as well as at Burning Man 2013 with two hosted events listed in Burning Man's What, Where, When event guide.

Lake Lahontan Point

Visiting a makeout spot has been as American as apple pie ever since the rise of American car culture in the 1950s. In honor of 2011’s “Rites of Passage” theme, and in collaboration with the Moonrock Collective, Lake Lahontan Point appeared on playa. Lake Lahontan Point was an installation consisting of three cars with custom radios in which participants could sit and enjoy the Black Rock City skyline. Hearkening back to countless movies and television shows, it was, in short, a makeout point. The cars were surrounded by greenery and looked out upon a model city skyline that bled into the real thing in the distance. The project was in part community-funded, and also received an art grant from Ignition Northwest. Its on-playa reception was extremely positive.

What We Need from You

Here's where you come in. We need your help to complete Simon Fire Edition! All of the work on Simon is being donated by our artists - thousands of hours of welding, software engineering, and design work. We also have a generous grant from Burning Man that will help pay for transportation and propane (which means we can shoot fire all night long). However, there is still a gap.

Your generous donation will go right where it's needed most: purchasing material and supplies. Simon is a complicated project, and requires:

  • 6,000 LED lights for the towers alone - 1,500 total watts of lighting
  • Hundreds of pounds of raw steel
  • Six Arduino microprocessors, and an ARM music processor
  • Several custom-designed circuit boards and electronics
  • Over 190 feet of propane plumbing, countless propane fittings, and 40 gallons of pressurized propane storage.

Your help will allow us to continue purchasing the supplies needed to complete Simon so that you can play with it!

Thank you so much for your support!

story:
THE FESTIVAL:

BOSH FESTIVAL – is an international multimedia platform that has been celebrating creative expressionisms in urban context for seven years now… Or put differently, BOSH is an attempt for estheticized articulation and deliberation of the so-called ‘added value’ to the urban culture.

BOSH is a process of creation of a typically different, extraordinary and unconventional public space… A space which is constantly re-defined throughout the urban arts, or respectively, the arts in urban context… A space which is unique and tangible enough, dynamic and pulsing, provocative and/or controversial… But above all, open and accessible to everyone!

BOSH is an ‘invasion upon the spirit’, an act of marking distinctively, a cultural and esthetic ‘free territory’! BOSH is a fusion and confusion, insofar as sensibilization and vulgarization too! BOSH is a linking-space in search of one’s own time and needs…

The festival usually happens during the last weekend of August at several public venues in Gevgelija (a town at the major border-crossing between Macedonia and Greece). During the three festival days  there will be many off-mainstream performances (professional and amateur), such as theatre, music, poetry, films and video-art, fine art exhibitions, workshops, graffiti sessions, and other forms of interdisciplinary as well as unconventional artistic happenings. All events are, and have always been free of charge…

The first edition of the BOSH FESTIVAL happened in 2009, in honor and memory of the late actor and poet Bosko Bozadzievski (1981-2008). It is a tribute by few of his close friends.

For more photos and info on past editions, please visit our website www.boshfest.com (to be updated soon), as well as our Facebook Page:

https://www.facebook.com/pages/BOSH-Festival/177229169014455?fref=ts


THE ORGANIZER:

ART EQUILIBRIUM - a local NGO that affirms the rationale for a dynamic as much as balanced societal development, specifically throughout arts and culture in urban context.

We believe the accessibility to arts and culture is one of the fundamental rights for each individual. And either as a ‘consumer’, or more importantly ‘producer’, throughout whose creativity and personal development, the totality of democratic, as well as socio-economic developments are also articulated and matured…

The sensibilization to a kind of a different and in many respects more qualitative creative expressionisms from the ones of the vulgarized triviality in the Balkans is constantly an actual priority… Therefore, the various forms of activism within the field of arts and culture became an inevitable characteristic of our activities, since the very beginnings in 2009…

BOSH Festival is completely funded by donations, sponsorships, and until recently some pitiful public funds that did not really match the socio-cultural magnitude and popularity of the festival, either home or abroad… However, as of the beginning of 2015, ART EQUILIBRIUM openly and publicly renounced these public funds, as these were disgracefully lowered, and thus answering the subtle pressure by the local elites. It was another statement and an act of anti-conformism to the orthodox political and bureaucratic establishments, for whom sadly enough, arts and culture still remain in the sphere of calculative, narrow-minded, muscle politics…


HOW THE MONEY WILL BE USED?

The funds are needed to cover the operating, as well as artists’ / performers’ travel costs. More specifically as follows:

1.  Audio-visual equipment (approx. 5.500 - 6.000 USD): Though we posses some of this equipment, it is not a fully professional one to the standard. As for the three days during the festival, we’ll need to rent this equipment. The best value for money we’ve found so far is as follows:

Audio equipment (concerts) incl. stage & lightning: 4.500-5.000 USD for 3 days

-  Aprox. some 10.000 W of power speakers and monitors

-  Quality mixer (40 channels min.)

-  Fully professional drum set

-  5 amplifiers (60-100W each min.)

-  Set of 10 quality microphones (shure, dynamic and condenser) with stands

-  Set of cables & connectors

-  2 audio technicians

Audio equipment: (films & video art) 500-700 USD for 3 days

This equipment will be needed for producing the audio during the film projections and video art.

-  Aprox. some 2.000 W of power speakers with stands

-  Quality mixer (8 channels min.)

-  Set of cables & connectors

-  Audio technician

Video equipment: (films & video art) 400-500 USD for 3 days

-  3 quality LCD video projectors

-  Standard video mixer (3 channels min.)

-  Video technician


2.  Travel costs, artists & performers (approx. 4.000 USD): The travel costs will be needed for approximately some 60 people.

-  Macedonia 30 – approx. 400 USD

-  Greece 10 – approx. 600 USD

-  Serbia 10 – approx. 500 USD

-  Rest of Europe (UK, France, Italy) 10 – approx. 2.500 USD


HOW YOUR CONTRIBUTION HELPS?

Apart from directly securing the continuity and quality of the festival, your contribution will make a real positive change in this part of the world… More specifically, on a long run it will help stimulate pragmatically an ideal balance between the conceptual instances as of cultural democracy / democratization of culture, in addition to assuring a qualitative improvement of the cultural and artistic offer at local level…

And as we do like to believe that revolutions happen in one’s mind first, your contribution will also have a great impact on the ideas as of accessibility to arts and culture, as much as essential decentralization within the field.

Finally, it will help the affirmation of the independent and alternative scene from all around the world, where BOSH Festival stands as a meeting point for the people to interact, regardless of their ethnicity, creed, race, or sexual orientation…


THE PERKS:

Dear friend / contributor,

Please understand that we are operating on a very tight budget, and therefore we’re not in a position to visually present our perks at the moment, as these will be produced ‘on the go’, and as we gain some funds to cover the costs of production. To this end, please allow us some time and flexibility when delivering the goods. However, we’re fully committed in acknowledging, and will be definitely rewarding your contribution.

In addition, please understand that here we also calculated the domestic taxes on income, which make a significant impact on the final formulation of the amounts. Sadly enough, these dues are not yet considerably exempted from such activities as arts and culture, nor activities of the NGO’s that are essentially non-for-profit.

We hope for your understanding and tolerance. For any questions and queries, please do not hesitate to contact us.

Best wishes,

BOSH Team.

story:
Who are we?


DISCLAIMER: Our monetary goal is not $12,000 it is $5,000! Indiegogo does not allow you to edit your money goal once you have given an initial amount...whoops! And thank you.  


Hello! We are a group of students at Bard College who were awarded a residency at Olana State Historic Site for the summer of 2015. We will get to the details of the residency in a minute; first, let us introduce ourselves. Our group is composed of 8 members either currently at Bard or recently graduated, brought together by an interest in working collaboratively. We are: Marion Albers, Denis Blumin, Serena Caffrey, Ethan Evans, Kai Mote, Cullan Powers, Ezra San Millan and Susie Yugler. To read more about each individual in the collective and to see samples of our work, please visit our web site.

We each study and work in different mediums at Bard, which makes the tools for collaboration fecund. And as much excitement and passion that we each feel towards our own respective mediums, there is as much excitement towards the idea of absorbing the skills of others, and sharing our ever-growing 'expertise' with other members of the group. Who knows what connections will arise when a sound installation artist tangoes with a poet on the grounds of Olana? 

This opportunity to collaborate will not only deepen our individual understanding of what it means to be an artist on this planet, but hopefully will also point to the futility of the idea that anything can be created in isolation, solely by the individual. Everything is the result of a collaboration between seen and unseen forces. By accepting this idea and acting as a collection of the vast individuals we are, we hope to create works that exceed what we could come up with on our own.


The Project

The residency is the first of its kind between Bard College and the Olana State Historic Site. It's part of Olana's River Crossings project, in which they invited several renowned contemporary artists (such as Chuck Close, Kiki Smith and Cindy Sherman) to create and show works on the grounds of Fredric Church's masterpiece. The task of our collective is to contribute living, creative energy to the grounds by making a work (or works) over the course of three months that will then be on display at Olana from August 30th until November 15th with an artist talk in September. Every Saturday and Sunday afternoon from 1-4 we will be at Olana, either in the studio they have provided us with (right behind the main house) or running around the grounds collecting and creating. Come visit us! This time requirement is to insure that the public may encounter us on the grounds or in our studio and acquaint themselves with the project. For us, this aspect of the residency is a blessing, because we believe that revealing the process of creation is just as important as presenting the finished product. The work-in-progress mode keeps us on our toes, and reminds people that art is not instantaneous, but is the result of an effort stemming from many (8) directions. 

While we are not entirely sure what the opening performance and installation will look like, please visit our Facebook page for photos and updates of the process! We will be posting regularly. Also, if you support us, we will send you snippets and updates via snailmail from on-site (see our perks section on the side).



The Site

Olana State Historic Site looms over the Rip Van Winkle bridge, 30 minutes north of Bard College. It is a capsule of both time and culture unparalleled in the Hudson Valley. Once the home and studio of prominent Hudson School painter Frederic Church, the site is now an official state park hosting thousands of visitors annually. Visit its website here. In addition to housing relics of Church's work and travels internationally, the house and grounds themselves are careful curations of Church's conservational and architectural vision. Even the viewshed (the surrounding lands and natural sites that constitute the view seen from Olana) is attributed to Church's genius, and remains within the intellectual property of the estate. 

How then do we create, in a setting thats every aspect is assumed to be part of the artistic vision of Mr. Frederic Church? Are we to assume that there is space for us to create today, as eight Bard students in 2015? Do we believe that his vision would permit for us to do so? 

We are creating anyway, so we must go ahead and assume that yes, there is space for us. Nonetheless, these are the sorts of questions that we can't help but feel are the important ones and which will undoubtedly figure into our work. We are not, after all, creating in an isolated bubble of self or school, but are immediately brought, as soon as we step onto the grounds of Olana, into the ongoing conversation about the ethics of conservation, of public vs. private property and of the intersection between landscape and art. We are excited to explore these relationships, and recognize that we are especially lucky to be working within an institution that promotes our inquiry into its workings. 


Why Indiegogo?

The funds we receive from Indiegogo support our project in two major ways. First, we hope to create installations of professional quality, which requires both artistic and financial capacity. With interest in sound, for example, such works require renting expensive equipment, speakers, and hardware. Due to a conflict with Bard's Masters in Fine Arts program, we also lack our usual access to our college's wood and metal shops, meaning we would have to rent power tools or access to shops in order to make sculptures of the scale and caliber we envision. Material costs add up fast, and, as students working in these disciplines we know this well... which brings us to the second outlet of financial support. Some members of our collective come from backgrounds that prohibit them from dedicating significant amounts of time and effort to extra-curricular activities for financial reasons. While many of us plan to work part-time jobs on top of our residency, those funds are still not sufficient for all members to cover the ever-pressing costs of housing, transportation and food. We ask for your support in order to provide group members with help to aid the cost of living. 

Challenges

This is an experiment for all members involved. We have little experience working collaboratively in a setting other than a classroom at Bard. In addition to learning how to overcome the daily difficulties of coordinating schedules and delegating administrative tasks, we are reconciling the creative vision and intellectual interests of eight independent artists. We are eager to take on this challenge because we believe that being forced to negotiate our varied interests and opinions will create stronger, wider work that could never have been born from just one of us and which will, in turn, positively effect our own individual creative practice. 


Thank you!

This project is something that will exist regardless of our success on Indiegogo. That said, we ask for your support, because we want to be able to create a work of value for the community that is uncompromised by our limited financial means. Your donation directly supports us in achieving this goal. We are a creative, inspired, and dedicated group- just visit us every Saturday and Sunday at Olana and see for yourselves! Thank you for your time and support; we appreciate every inch.

The Project

The residency is the first of its kind between
Bard College and the Olana State Historic Site.
It's part of Olana's River Crossings project,
in which they invited several renowned contemporary artists (such as Chuck
Close, Kiki Smith and Cindy Sherman) to create and show works on the grounds of
Fredric Church's masterpiece. The task of our collective is to contribute
living, creative energy to the grounds by making a work (or works) over the
course of three months that will then be on display at Olana from August 30th
until November 15th with an artist talk in September. Every Saturday and Sunday
afternoon from 1-4 we will be at Olana, either in the studio they have provided
us with (right behind the main house) or running around the grounds collecting
and creating. Come visit us! This time requirement is to insure that the public
may encounter us on the grounds or in our studio and acquaint themselves with
the project. For us, this aspect of the residency is a blessing, because we
believe that revealing the process of creation is just as
important as presenting the finished product. The work-in-progress mode keeps
us on our toes, and reminds people that art is not instantaneous, but is the result of an effort stemming from many (8) directions. 
While we are not entirely sure what the
opening performance and installation will look like, please visit our Facebook page for photos and updates of the
process! We will be posting regularly. Also, if you support us, we will send you snippets and updates via snailmail from on-site (see our perks section on the side).



   The Site


Olana State Historic Site looms over the Rip Van Winkle bridge, 30 minutes north of Bard College. It is a capsule of both time and culture unparalleled in the Hudson Valley. Once the home and studio of prominent Hudson School painter Frederic Church, the site is now an official state park hosting thousands of visitors annually. Visit its website here. In addition to housing relics of Church's work and travels internationally, the house and grounds themselves are careful curations of Church's conservational and architectural vision. Even the viewshed (the surrounding lands and natural sites that constitute the view seen from Olana) is attributed to Church's genius, and remains within the intellectual property of the estate. 
How then do we create, in a setting thats every aspect is assumed to be part of the artistic vision of Mr. Frederic Church? Are we to assume that there is space for us to create today, as eight Bard students in 2015? Do we believe that his vision would permit for us to do so? 
We are creating anyway, so we must go ahead and assume that yes, there is space for us. Nonetheless, these are the sorts of questions that we can't help but feel are the important ones and which will undoubtedly figure into our work. We are not, after all, creating in an isolated bubble of self or school, but are immediately brought, as soon as we step onto the grounds of Olana, into the ongoing conversation about the ethics of conservation, of public vs. private property and of the intersection between landscape and art. We are excited to explore these relationships, and recognize that we are especially lucky to be working within an institution that promotes our inquiry into its workings. 



Why Indiegogo?
 The funds we receive from Indiegogo support our project in two major ways. First, we hope to create installations of professional quality, which requires both artistic and financial capacity. With interest in sound, for example, such works require renting expensive equipment, speakers, and hardware. Due to a conflict with Bard's Masters in Fine Arts program, we also lack our usual access to our college's wood and metal shops, meaning we would have to rent power tools or access to shops in order to make sculptures of the scale and caliber we envision. Material costs add up fast, and, as students working in these disciplines we know this well... which brings us to the second outlet of financial support. Some members of our collective come from backgrounds that prohibit them from dedicating significant amounts of time and effort to extra-curricular activities for financial reasons. While many of us plan to work part-time jobs on top of our residency, those funds are still not sufficient for all members to cover the ever-pressing costs of housing, transportation and food. We ask for your support in order to provide group members with help to aid the cost of living. 
Challenges
  This is an experiment for all members involved. We have little experience working collaboratively in a setting other than a classroom at Bard. In addition to learning how to overcome the daily difficulties of coordinating schedules and delegating administrative tasks, we are reconciling the creative vision and intellectual interests of eight independent artists. We are eager to take on this challenge because we believe that being forced to negotiate our varied interests and opinions will create stronger, wider work that could never have been born from just one of us and which will, in turn, positively effect our own individual creative practice. Thank you!This project is something that will exist regardless of our success on Indiegogo. That said, we ask for your support, because we want to be able to create a work of value for the community that is uncompromised by our limited financial means. Your donation directly supports us in achieving this goal. We are a creative, inspired, and dedicated group- just visit us every Saturday and Sunday at Olana and see for yourselves! Thank you for your time and support; we appreciate every inch.

story:
After our success with Tales of the North, we are delighted to announce our new campaign: Dog’s Life. This campaign is a collaboration between talented sculptor Vladimir Danilov and CASTLE Miniatures. Our main goal is to show men through the eyes of their pets.

First 3 figures are:

 

British officer with a pug in colonial uniforms (East India or Martinique – 1793).

 

 

A private soldier during Napoleonic wars with a mongrel.

 

 

And another British officer during Napoleonic wars.

 

It total, we plan a present you with a line of at least 7 figures. Different times, different people, different dogs.

IMPORTANT INFO:

Based on our experience with first campaign, this time we've decided to produce figures as soon as you choose your perks. This way, we will be ready to ship them right after this campaign is ended.

SHIPPING RATE:

$10 Worldwide

Giclee prints of playful drawings that led to the creation of some of the art work presented in the video. Giclee Prints are high quality prints made on Fine Art Archival, watercolor paper using Archival Pigmented Inks.

With this wonderful print you also get: + The $20 'Postcard Collection' gift. 

Choose only one of the following and email me your choice.

Wooden Art

'Lady Nature', 15" H X 18" W (38cm H x46cm W). A hand-finished art piece made of wood. With this piece you also get: + The $40 'Art Catalog' gift.

                       

                   

                                                                           

Colored Art 

$420

A hand-painted & hand-finished unique art piece made of wood. With this piece you also get: + The $40 'Art Catalog' gift. Choose one of the following and email me your choice:      

1. 'Lady Nature', 15" H X 18" W (38cm H x 46cm W). 

          


2. 'Hunter', 15" H X 18" W (38cm H x 46cm W).  

            


              



                                                    Summary of the Rewards 




                                                          Stretch Goals


Risks & Challenges

Please bear in mind that the dates are a good estimate of how long it will take me to complete and send you all the gifts. More than 100% funding might require for the project to be extended due to the larger demand. In this case, all backers will receive a more accurate timeline in a post-funding project update. 

FAQ

I am interested to make a large order for one of your perks, can you make me a better offer for large quantities?

Yes, it is possible to get a more affordable price for large quantities. Please contact me to discuss this possibility and reach an agreement.

What about international shipping?

Shipping internationally will be done primarily through registered post with tracking number. To make it easier for you shipping is included in all the perks. 

Bear in mind that for countries within the EU there will be no additional customs charged, but for countries outside the EU there might be additional importation taxes/customs fees upon delivery and these are not included in the price. The custom fees vary from country to country and the policies of your country.

Can I make multiple perks?

It's exciting to hear that you've found multiple perks you are interested in claiming! Please note, at this time, Indiegogo does not have a feature for you to be able to add multiple perks in a single transaction. As such, if you'd like to claim multiple perks, please make a new contribution for each perk.

For any other questions please sent me a message through Indiegogo or contact me via e-mail at stellakarageorgi@hotmail.com

If you can't contribute but still like my art, please spread the word around and support an artist with a vision. You can use Indiegogo's share tool, Facebook sharing, email and word of mouth. Thank you!

story:
Hi

I am an artist and curator living and working in Atlanta, GA. I will be participating in a program called "Chopped, Except that it's Art Chopped" this fall. I am raising funds to travel to New York City and attend the program at The Bruce High Quality Foundation University (BHQFU). The seven week course, taught by Sean J Patrick Carney, revolves around the challenge to create an unforgettable body of work from mystery art supplies before time runs out. 
This is an incredible learning opportunity for me. It will be a challenge to create meaningful work under pressure, a challenge I am confident that I will rise to. Also, immersing myself in another city's art scene will give me a fresh perspective on my practice and allow me to grow immensely as an artist and curator. I am always looking for feedback on my work and getting it, for better or for worse, from the program's stellar cast of judges including Jayson Musson, Chloe Wise, Brian Droitcour and many others will be invauable. 
 

Why I Need Your help

The class at BHQFU is free but I will need funds to get to New York and back. I will also need to live in the city, eat, and get around for two months during the program. Even if I do not reach my campaign goal, I will still receive the funds and go so anything you can contribute will help a lot. 

 

Perks

As a small token of my gratitude, I have included some perks for contributing to my campaign. Perks include limited edition prints, zines, and original digital artworks.

 

("Bae This Could Be Us" art zine, 2014)

 

About Me

I am an artist, curator, and writer living and working in Atlanta, GA. My multidisciplinary work examines the element of context and its effect on subjective experience. I've exhibited nationally and internationally. My work has been written about in publications such as Burnaway, Creative Loafing, and Art Papers. In 2013, I founded The LOW Museum and have since served as executive director and chief curator. In 2015, I was selected as a finalist for the Forward Arts Foundation's Emerging Artist Award, I participated in Wonderroot's CSA (season 6) and will exhibit in the City of Atlanta's annual public exhibition ELEVATE. Your contribution will help advance my career as a promising emerging artist and foster exchange between these two great cities. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you cannot contribute you can still help. Share this campaign on social media, send me your warm energy that I might survive the blistering New York cold or just send me a message to say hi. Thank you again for your generous support ;)

story:
Hello my name is Andrew Smart. I am a professional artist, published children’s book illustrator and co-founder of Call That Art Gallery .

I've been a professional artist for 12 years now. I started as a freelance artist after I graduated from high school in 2003. My style is a blend of traditional and modern so my choice of medium often varies. However, I have worked in pen and ink, and pencil (black/white) for most of my career. I started off illustrating comic books; to me comic book art was, and still is the definition of art. From the dynamic movement to the subtle glances, you can always form a story even if it is not in sequential order.

Page from the comic book, "TBD, The Death Of The Hopeless Romantic"

Nowadays I don’t stray too far from that comic art influence, but I am broadening my horizons. I am getting more into classical art, starting to move into color a bit, (and by the way, I have tons of respect for colorists), but no matter what changes I like giving all my pieces that dynamic action feel that comic book art exudes. I like to give my pieces that “there’s a story behind this” feel that you get from comic book art. I’m definitely still growing as an artist and that’s what I absolutely love about art, there is always something else to explore.

What is Call That Art

Call that Art is a family owned and operated art gallery.

Our Gallery in Florida

God has blessed me with an amazingly talented family. My mom, my dad, brothers, and aunts, all have different styles and they all bring something fantastic to the table.

"Me and the Mommsie!"

I owe a lot to my mom because she was my first influence as an artist and her work still influences me. When I was little I used to copy the artwork she made, then she would review it and critique it. I’ve learned a lot from my mom.

Unpredictability and Spontaneity

The elements of unpredictability and spontaneity are part of the uniqueness of Call that Art. With so many different styles and art pieces under one roof there is always something new and exciting to experience whether you're at the gallery or at a Call That Art event.

"Draw Your Sword"

"Social Flower"

How We Got Started

Call That Art started the 3rd of August, 2013. I was in Florida looking for galleries to represent me. The more I looked, the more I felt my style didn't really fit in with the motifs and themes that the galleries were presenting.

Long story short we found an awesome location right along the beach and we’ve been there ever since. Our initial five short minutes of discussion turned into five LONG months of preparation! Finally, in December 2013, we held our grand opening. Even though it was small we had a great turn-out and lots of positive feedback.

Over the past 2 years we’ve been busy working hard, traveling, doing shows and getting the word out about Call That Art. We all feel that is the right time to host another Call That Art event, this time in Washington, DC.

Yea...That's Rufio (Dante Basco to those of you who are not Hook fans).

Why DC??

I have already been given opportunities to showcase my art in DC at gallery shows and at comic conventions. Every time I go the reception is amazing and I strongly feel DC is going to be the next mecca for art and artists. I definitely want Call That Art to be a part of the foundation.

Get to the point

Okay, I would like your help to host a two day “I Call That Art” solo art event. This show will focus on my artwork, but with your help this success will give us the opportunity to do more shows in DC as a family.

My girlfriend Michele (co-founder of Comic Cupcakes and one of our artists) and I have coordinated other shows and events in the past, but this will be our most ambitious attempt to date. From venue, to the food, drink and entertainment, we want this to be a “can't miss” event.

Michele Miliante, Co-Founder of Comic Cupcakes

Art Identity Expo: Latino Heritage Celebration 2014. Call That Art was a sponsor, and Michele and I were the Event Coordinators. 

Our financial goal is $10,000

Once again this is a very ambitious venture for us, but through our research we concluded that $10,000 would help us cover the expenses for:

  • The Venue: Your contribution will help us rent space, decorate, and take care any other expenses pertaining to the venue for where the art show will be held.
  • Supplies: Inks, paints, prints, canvases, and clay, your contribution will help pay for supplies to create all the art that I will be showing.
  • Perks and shipping: Your contribution will make sure that all of the cool rewards will be made with quality materials and that they’ll be shipped in a timely manner.
  • Entertainment: We want to have live entertainment (i.e., music, DJ, spoken word artist, etc) during the show, and of course we would like to have the finances to pay them for their talents!
  • Refreshments: Your contribution will help us make sure that our you are not going hungry at the event. With you contribution we will be able to hire a caterer to help with the food and beverages.
  • Press and Publicity: We want to take this event to another level and that requires publicity. With your contribution we can get the news of the I Call That Art to everyone through social media, newspapers, magazine ads, signs and and even Television spots.

Perks

Now let's get down to the good stuff. We have put a lot of time and thought into these perks not only to make sure that you will be getting a lot of cool and exclusive stuff, but also so you will be able to see the promising future for Call That Art as clearly as I see it, and feel proud that you were among the first to be a part of this movement.

I Call That Art Movement

*Some print designs will only be available in certain sizes.There will be a designated gallery for each print size in order to prevent image distortion. To see which prints are available in the size you would like, please click on the gallery tab at the top of the page.*

$5 Thank You Post Card

You will receive an exclusive hand written Call That Art thank you post card.

$15 8x10 Print

You will receive any 8x10 print of choosing from the designated 8x10 gallery. All prints will be printed with the highest quality ink on Mohawk cardstock.

$20 signed Comic and poem book

You will receive a signed copy of TBD, a 32 page black and white comic book that I co-wrote and illustrated along with the official TBD poem book. The poem book is a selection of writings from the creator Michael Mills. The poems were the inspiration that prompted the creation of the comic TBD.

$35 Call That Art Shirt

You will receive an “I Call That Art” t-shirt in the size of your choosing. Shirts will be available in three colors, black, white, and grey.

$40 11x17 print

You will receive any print of your choosing from the 11x17 gallery. All prints will be printed with the highest quality ink on Mohawk cardstock.

$60 13x19

You will receive any print of your choosing from the 13x19  gallery. All prints will be printed with the highest quality ink on Mohawk cardstock.

$100 2 13x19

You will receive any TWO prints of your choosing from the 13x19 gallery. That’s a $120 value! As with all the others, all prints will be printed with the highest quality ink on Mohawk cardstock.

I call that inspiration

$200 11x14 

You will receive an original portrait inspired by you, the backer and as an added bonus, you will be part of the show! Your potrait will be showcased in the I Call That Art Show.

"Happah"

All you need to do is send in a photo of yourself (head shot).

*Please refrain from exhibiting any lewd behavior or using profane hand gestures in your photo, thank you.

$300 18x20 Canvas Piece

You will get to choose from 4 designs and we will put that design on a professional art canvas that will be ready to go up on your wall as soon as it arrives.

Risks?

Honestly I can’t think of any risks. Art is my passion and I’m going to pursue it with everything I have. The risk that my dream will never become a reality if I don’t give my art all my attention is the only risk that scares me.

Thank You!

We would like to thank you for taking the time to check us out. We would appreciate any pledge you can make to our campaign. If you can’t make a financial donation you can always donate the gift of sharing this campaign with your friends, neighbors, or strangers…the good kind of strangers…not the stranger dangers. Lol, every bit helps. Use the Indiegogo share tools and help make this dream a reality!

I pray that it is God’s will this campaign will be a success and that we move forward with this show so again thank you in advance for your support.
story_txt:
Hello my name is Andrew Smart. I am a
professional artist, published children’s book illustrator and co-founder of
Call That Art Gallery .
I've been a professional artist for 12
years now. I started as a freelance artist after I graduated from high school
in 2003. My style is a blend of traditional and modern so my choice of medium
often varies. However, I have worked in pen and ink, and pencil (black/white) for most of my career.
I started off illustrating comic books; to me comic book art was, and still is
the definition of art. From the dynamic movement to the subtle glances, you can
always form a story even if it is not in sequential order.Page from the comic book, "TBD, The Death Of The Hopeless Romantic"Nowadays I don’t stray too far from that
comic art influence, but I am broadening my horizons. I am getting more into classical
art, starting to move into color a bit, (and by the way, I have tons of respect
for colorists), but no matter what changes I like giving all my pieces that
dynamic action feel that comic book art exudes. I like to give my pieces that
“there’s a story behind this” feel that you get from comic book art. I’m definitely
still growing as an artist and that’s what I absolutely love about art, there
is always something else to explore.
What is Call That Art
Call that Art is a family owned
and operated art gallery.


Our Gallery in Florida

God has blessed me with an amazingly
talented family. My mom, my dad, brothers, and aunts, all have different styles
and they all bring something fantastic to the table. 


"Me and the Mommsie!"
I owe a lot to my mom because she was my
first influence as an artist and her work still influences me. When I was
little I used to copy the artwork she made, then she would review it and
critique it. I’ve learned a lot from my mom.

Unpredictability and Spontaneity
The elements of unpredictability and
spontaneity are part of the uniqueness of Call that Art. With so many different
styles and art pieces under one roof there is always something new and exciting
to experience whether you're at the gallery or at a Call That Art event. 


"Draw Your Sword"

"Social Flower"
How We Got Started
Call That Art started the 3rd of August, 2013. I
was in Florida looking for galleries to represent me. The more I looked, the
more I felt my style didn't really fit in with the motifs and themes that the
galleries were presenting.
Long story short we found an awesome
location right along the beach and we’ve been there ever since. Our initial five
short minutes of discussion turned into five LONG months of preparation!
Finally, in December 2013, we held our grand opening. Even though it was small
we had a great turn-out and lots of positive feedback. 
Over the past 2 years we’ve been busy working hard, traveling, doing shows and getting the word out about Call That Art. We all feel that is the right time to host another Call That Art event, this time in Washington, DC.




Yea...That's Rufio (Dante Basco to those of you who are not Hook fans).
Why DC??
I have already been given opportunities to
showcase my art in DC at gallery shows and at comic conventions. Every time I
go the reception is amazing and I strongly feel DC is going to be the next
mecca for art and artists. I definitely want Call That Art to be a part of the
foundation.
Get to the point
Okay, I would like your help to host a two day “I Call That Art” solo art event. This show will focus on my artwork, but with your help this success will give us the opportunity to do more shows in DC as a family.
My girlfriend Michele (co-founder of Comic
Cupcakes and one of our artists) and I have coordinated other shows and events
in the past, but this will be our most ambitious attempt to date. From venue, to
the food, drink and entertainment, we want this to be a “can't miss” event.



Michele Miliante, Co-Founder of Comic Cupcakes







Art Identity Expo: Latino Heritage Celebration 2014. Call That Art was a sponsor, and Michele and I were the Event Coordinators. 

Our financial goal is $10,000
Once again this is a very ambitious
venture for us, but through our research we concluded that $10,000 would help
us cover the expenses for:



The Venue: Your contribution will help us
rent space, decorate, and take care any other expenses pertaining to the venue for
where the art show will be held.


Supplies: Inks, paints, prints, canvases,
and clay, your contribution will help pay for supplies to create all the art
that I will be showing.


Perks and shipping: Your contribution
will make sure that all of the cool rewards will be made with quality materials
and that they’ll be shipped in a timely manner.


Entertainment: We want to have live entertainment (i.e.,
music, DJ, spoken word artist, etc) during the show, and of course we would
like to have the finances to pay them for their talents!


Refreshments: Your contribution will help us make sure
that our you are not going hungry at the event. With you contribution we will
be able to hire a caterer to help with the food and beverages.


Press and Publicity: We want to take this event to another level
and that requires publicity. With your contribution we can get the news of the
I Call That Art to everyone through social media, newspapers, magazine ads,
signs and and even Television spots.




Perks
Now let's get down to the good stuff. We have put a lot of time and thought into these perks not only to make sure that you will be
getting a lot of cool and exclusive stuff, but also so you will be able to see the promising future for Call That Art as clearly as I see it, and feel proud that you were among the
first to be a part of this movement.
I Call That Art Movement
*Some print designs will only be available in certain sizes.There will be a designated gallery for each print size in order to prevent image distortion. To see which prints are available in the size you would like, please click on the gallery tab at the top of the page.*
$5 Thank You Post Card



You will receive an exclusive hand written Call That Art thank you post card.
$15 8x10 Print
You will receive any 8x10 print of choosing from the designated 8x10 gallery. All prints will be printed with the highest quality ink on Mohawk cardstock.
$20 signed Comic and poem book


You will receive a signed copy of TBD, a 32 page black and
white comic book that I co-wrote and illustrated along with the official TBD
poem book. The poem book is a selection of writings from the creator Michael
Mills. The poems were the inspiration that prompted the creation of the comic
TBD.
$35 Call That Art Shirt
You will receive an “I
Call That Art” t-shirt in the size of your choosing. Shirts will be
available in three colors, black, white, and grey.




$40 11x17 print

You will receive any print of your choosing from the 11x17
gallery. All prints will be printed with the highest quality ink on Mohawk
cardstock. 
$60 13x19
You will receive any print of your choosing from the
13x19  gallery. All prints will be
printed with the highest quality ink on Mohawk cardstock.
$100 2 13x19
You will receive any TWO prints of your choosing from the 13x19
gallery. That’s a $120 value! As with all the others, all prints will be
printed with the highest quality ink on Mohawk cardstock.
I call that inspiration
$200 11x14 
You will receive an original portrait inspired by you, the
backer and as an added bonus, you will be part of the show! Your potrait will be showcased in the I Call That Art Show.

All you need to do is send in a photo of yourself
(head shot).
*Please refrain from exhibiting any lewd behavior or using
profane hand gestures in your photo, thank you.
$300 18x20 Canvas Piece
You will get to choose from 4 designs and we will put that design on a professional art canvas that will be ready to go up on your wall as soon as it arrives.

Risks?
Honestly I can’t think of any risks. Art is my passion and I’m going to pursue it with everything I have. The risk that my dream will never become a reality if I don’t give my art all my attention is the only risk that scares me.
Thank You!
We would like to thank you for taking the time to check us out. We would appreciate any pledge you can make to our campaign. If you can’t make a financial donation you can always donate the gift of sharing this campaign with your friends, neighbors, or strangers…the good kind of strangers…not the stranger dangers. Lol, every bit helps. Use the Indiegogo share tools and help make this dream a reality!
I pray that it is God’s will this campaign will be a success and that we move forward with this show so again thank you in advance for your support.

story:
Short Summary

M.I.is an Art Exhibition to make the audience think. 

  • I am an uprising curator, in her early 20s thinking about using art to create a better world.
  • M.I. exhibition will be the first show I curate. 
  • Addressing on the topic of who we are and the effect of personal interaction, leveraging spacial relations of installed pieces. 
  • Your contribution will support the success of the exhibition, help to inspire others. 
  • Here is the flyer with a development of the thesis:


What We Need & What You Get

Here is the budget sheet I made with the detailed list of what we need;

  • overall it is a $561 total goal. you can choose to support us by donating $2.5, $5, $10, $25, $50, $75, $100 and over, or any other specific amount that you want to contribute. =]
  • I will send out all together 50 customized postcards to our contributors. each with a handpick shot taken in the gallery. In order to receive the perk, make sure you let me know your mailing address.=] 
  • If the funding isn't enough, I will use whatever that has been raised to hold the event. Any amount go over the total goal will be deposit to the next show I curate. 
  • here are screenshots of the budget sheet that I have made, in case our dear contributors want a detailed look:

    (apologies for the cut-off, which is the only way to make the numbers big enough for everyone to see)

    I also uploaded the original sheet onto google sheets just in case anyone want to keep track of updated numbers, here is the link:

    https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1bC_GkP4...

The Impact

Self Identification plays an important part in our lives.

  • However, hectic life sometimes gives us no time/energy to consider this important topic.
  • Modern Settings can be different and cause more difficulty for answers to yield.
  • Sometimes even I feel lost, driven by nothing for going nowhere in life, which sucks and brings a lot of troubles which will hinder a happy life.
  • Your contribution will financially make the exhibition happen in a professional level, creating an opportunity for all the visitor of the exhibition and their friends and families to find their answers to the essential question. Your contribution will inspire people.
  • I will also got encouraged in my work, producing more and more inspiring exhibitions. And one day in one of the world's greatest exhibitions, I will remember your initial help. 

Risks & Challenges

Here are some potential challenges and solutions:

  • 1, lack of experience; 2, distant location of the gallery;3,  hardship during installation
  • I always love challenges. Challenges are always what make the day great. The process of overcoming them are fun and giving a sense of achievement. 
  • Specific solutions to each potential situation: 1, referring to mentors regarding the management of the exhibition; 2, the curator will always be available for arranging visits, offering transportation to guests;3, solid installation plan will be made at the beginning of installation 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are passionate about the program, you can always make couple clicks with your mouse:

  • share it to Facebook friends or using "Word of Mouth" strategy
  • click like on our Facebook page and leave comments to inspire the world!

And that's all there is to it.


Appreciate your attention.

Glad to have you as a part of our mission to empower mankind.

Please looking forward to your postcards.=]

Again, my sincere thanks. 

Jingyi/Karen Wang

story:
Summary

WY PHEE Collective is a concept that came together over the course of many years. As long-time friends, Amy Lennox and myself have been making our mark on different aspects of the art and music word for much of our lives. Having built strong relationships with cutting-edge, brilliant modern & underground artists in the US, we felt it was time to band our forces together and make a positive impact in the art community. Drawing much inspiration from the impact and responsibilities artists have in making a name and scene for ourselves within an existing community, WY PHEE was born. 

We plan to showcase our inaugural collection in Wynwood Miami during Art Basel on December 2nd through the 6th. 

The collaborative effort is a blend of eclectic art, music, jewelry and live performance. This diverse agglomerate was conceptualized with the mission of bringing forth the essence of true artists and their individual fervor by giving back to the cummunity and sharing our tremendous vibe with hopes of making an impact in the local scene.

“That all of our artists and curators in WY PHEE Collective share in my enthusiasm confirms that we are truly involved in something great” – Laura Rickles; Co-Founder

WY PHEE will feature two headlining artists whose not-so-similar styles are both magnificent and eccentric. The expansive space makes way for large statement pieces as well as some smaller noteworthy pieces for art collectors of all demographics. Each day will have a running LIVE art performance, including a cutting edge hydrodip performance, inviting you to dance through the depths of the artists’ imagination. The folks at Mixcloud will be on hand showcasing their feature channel – Access Underground. The channel aims to re-think radio and help connect listeners with the best DJs and radio presenters in the world. The series spotlights prominent & rising underground dance music talent from around the globe to ensure the atmosphere is insurmountable.

Rounding out the collective will be a stunning jewelry presentation by Lu-Kai whose one of a kind statement pieces have graced the heads of many burning man enthusiasts, and G2B5 jewelry from recycled material. Both designed to suit each individuals taste and personal style. 

We are bringing all of this forth now because we believe in our artists and their talent and the beauty that lies within each person involved in the collective. It starts with love, and is passed on to eachother through the light and positivity in each of us and we hope to be able to share, even if it's a small piece, this energy with our collective and the rest of the world. 

We are HONORED to be working with Art Cares for Kids, a Miami-based nonprofit organization comprised of volunteers who serve children in medical settings dealing with psychological, emotional and physical challenges. We are set to do daily raffles of select pieces by our artists, the proceeds from the raffles going to this fantastic organization.


What We Need & What You Get

At this point in the curation, we have exhausted all of our resources as well as personal accounts. Renting the raw space has been secured but the challenge ahead lies in all of the loose ends such as lighting, sound equipment, and transportation for our artwork and equipment. We also require some miscellaneous pieces of the puzzle such as printing fliers, banners and other merchandising expenses our friends aren't doing for us already pro bono. 

We are extremely low-maintenance and resourceful and have mapped out ways to accomplish our goals for a very low budget that will not take way from the aesthetic. Our hope is to gain enough money from this fund to meet these loose ends head on and go into our maiden showcase with confidence as we showcase what we know to be truly magnificent artists.

In appreciation of our investors we have artist prints, and original artworks from our gracious artists. All of our investors who donate over $25 will gain VIP entry to our opening night event on Dec 3rd.
Works of art by our featured artists are posted in this summary and are direct examples of the works that will be received by our donors as a part of our perks.

The Impact

We are bringing all of this forth now because we believe in our artists and their talent and the beauty that lies within each person involved in the collective. We also STRONGLY believe in the power of art to strengthen our community. It starts with love, and is passed on to eachother through the light and positivity in each of us and we hope to be able to share, even if it's a small piece, this energy with our collective, and the rest of the world. 

Risks & Challenges

We seem to have a multitude of moving parts involved in this project. One of which being the musical aspect. The challenge here is to coordinate and get all of our artists scheduled and also equipment rentals alligned to form a cohesive schedule. We are confident that through the use of contracts as well as constant communication and strong organization that this is a potential obstacle that will be overcome.

Additionally, our artists are traveling with large fragile pieces of art, travel in any circumstance poses a threat as far as inclement weather etc. We have devised a plan where we have rented a vehicle and mapped the route starting in Marthas Vineyard, and will be having a driver pick up the artwork a week in advance to allow for safe travel times, a margin of error and time to get the space set up.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are open to any Wy Phee Collective honorary members that want to spread our message and support our mission. 

If in Miami we encourage you to come to our space and check out our show and artwork! We'd love to meet you.

story:
Can You Think of Anyone Else You'd Trust With a DEATHRAY?

Hey everyone, I'm Ben Hamby (the guy on the left) and I make stuff. Lots of stuff. I'm supposed to talk about myself in this part, but I'll try and keep it brief. I'm an artist, maker, author, costumer, actor, cosplayer, chef, and world traveler with a passionate need to learn and expand my own (and others') horizons. I also occasionally manage to make things that people like to buy. Lately, that has included a bunch of items that have to be cut on a laser. An opportunity to get a fully-functional, self-contained laser has arisen, and I did a dumb thing. Like, I talked to one of these guys...

... got a personal loan, and at the time of writing this I am packing up to go pick up a laser. Because I tend to get excited about things, consequences be damned.

I Get A Laser... What's In It For YOU?

The total amount listed above covers the cost of the laser, the computer dedicated to it, the cooling and ventilation system, the trip to retrieve all of this concentrated awesome (including the trailer, gas, hotel, etc), repaying the loan, and of course the fees gathered by our friends here at Indie-Go-Go. 

So what do you get? AWESOME STUFF! The perks will have prizes at almost every level, including my extremely popular lamps, like this one...

...bookmarks and key-chains, holsters, custom leather work, cosplay props, foam armor (think Iron Man), or just hours of my dedicated time to work on YOUR projects.

Why This Is A Big Deal

The lasers at any shared shop are exactly that... shared. I have to book time at the TechShop in 2 hour intervals per day, which is barely enough time to cut ONE of my Hellraiser lamps.  (seen here - two hours of cutting, several more of sanding, staining and gluing, and.. oh yeah, a lifetime in the Pain Dimension.)

Even with the extremely lenient shop hours, there are times that I need to be able to work overnight. Having a laser at the house will both free up an enormous block of drive time as well as remove all scheduling limitations. It means more products in more people's hands sooner. It also means that experimentation with new materials and the development of new projects won't have to be scheduled and limited to a time slot. This is an 80 watt laser with all the trimmings, which is the perfect power range for the wood and leather that I use most often. It's also powerful enough to really get into some interesting additional choices for materials, but it's still short of cutting metal. In short, reduced costs in time, travel, and materials can be passed on to you.

What Happens If This Fails?

To you guys? Nothing much. I will honor all orders and donations even if it means making them on TechShop lasers and within their time-frame, so if you're concerned about getting your stuff - don't be. Worst case scenario on your end is not very worst case - it just means waiting a while for me to make it through the orders. To me? Ummmmm...

Remember this guy?
If you just throw a couple of bucks at this in order to support me, it will do exactly that and you will have my heartfelt gratitude. If this succeeds? As soon as the laser is up and running down here, all prize support goes out FIRST. Finally, if you 'buy' my time (one of the perks is exactly that), you have it - on a TechShop laser, at a workshop, or at your place. This laser is a huge step for me, and will change my lamp making from a hobby to a business. Paying back the loan means that I get to keep my teeth.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • I'm using the Indie-Go-Go template directly here. If you aren't able to contribute, please just get the word out and make some noise about my campaign by sharing this thing EVERYWHERE! They even have share tools embedded right into the listing.
